question: Question 1 An isotropic brittle material is tested in the universal testing machine. The stress strain diagram for the material shows a bi-linear elastic behavior as shown in the figure given below. The strain energy density is ________ [latex]MJm^{-3} [/latex](rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given: Stress-strain diagram shows a bilinear elastic behavior. Area under the stress-strain curve gives the strain energy density (U), in [latex] \text{MJ/m}^3 [/latex]. We can compute the total area under the curve as the sum of the areas of: • A triangle from [latex] 0 [/latex] to [latex] \epsilon = 0.01 [/latex] with [latex] \sigma = 100 \, \text{MPa} [/latex] • A trapezoid from [latex] \epsilon = 0.01 [/latex] to [latex] 0.015 [/latex] with [latex] \sigma = 100 \text{ to } 120 \, \text{MPa} [/latex] Step 1: Area of triangle (up to 0.01 strain) [latex] A_1 = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height} = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 0.01 \cdot 100 = 0.5 \, \text{MJ/m}^3 [/latex] Step 2: Area of trapezoid (from 0.01 to 0.015 strain) Average stress = [latex] \frac{100 + 120}{2} = 110 \, \text{MPa} [/latex] Strain interval = [latex] 0.015 - 0.01 = 0.005 [/latex] [latex] A_2 = 110 \cdot 0.005 = 0.55 \, \text{MJ/m}^3 [/latex] Total strain energy density: [latex] U = A_1 + A_2 = 0.5 + 0.55 = \boxed{1.05 \, \text{MJ/m}^3} [/latex]

question: Question 2 A simply supported beam of length 1 m is subjected to a uniformly distributed bending moment of 1 N m per m throughout the length as shown in the figure given below. The bending moment at the mid-point of the beam is _____N m (rounded off to the nearest integer).
solution: Given: Simply supported beam of length [latex] L = 1 \, \text{m} [/latex] Uniformly distributed bending moment of [latex] 1 \, \text{Nm/m} [/latex] applied along the length Note: This is not a usual uniformly distributed load (UDL), but a uniformly distributed bending moment , which is a theoretical case and is different in analysis. For such a case, the bending moment at any section of a simply supported beam under a uniformly distributed moment [latex] m_0 [/latex] (in Nm/m) is given by: [latex] M(x) = m_0 \left( \frac{L}{2} - x \right) [/latex] Where [latex] x [/latex] is measured from the left support, and [latex] m_0 = 1 \, \text{Nm/m} [/latex] At mid-span: [latex] x = \frac{L}{2} = 0.5 \, \text{m} [/latex] So, [latex] M(0.5) = 1 \cdot \left( \frac{1}{2} - 0.5 \right) = 0 [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{0 \, \text{Nm}} [/latex]

question:
Question 4 The endurance limit of a specific grade of steel is same as its yield strength. The
ultimate strength of this grade of steel is twice of its yield strength. A component
made of this steel is loaded in tension and unloaded periodically. It is required that
the component does NOT fail for at least [latex]10^{6}[/latex] loading cycles, as per the Soderberg law. Considering a factor of safety of 2, the maximum applied tensile principal
stress is
solution: Given: Endurance limit = Yield strength = [latex] \sigma_y [/latex] Ultimate strength = [latex] 2\sigma_y [/latex] Factor of safety (FOS) = 2 Loading is fully tensile and periodic (i.e., reversed loading) Life requirement: at least [latex]10^6[/latex] cycles → high-cycle fatigue Use Soderberg criterion for design Step 1: Soderberg Equation The Soderberg criterion is: [latex] \frac{\sigma_a}{\sigma_e} + \frac{\sigma_m}{\sigma_y} \leq \frac{1}{\text{FOS}} [/latex] Where: [latex] \sigma_a [/latex] = alternating stress = [latex] \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}} - \sigma_{\text{min}}}{2} [/latex] [latex] \sigma_m [/latex] = mean stress = [latex] \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}} + \sigma_{\text{min}}}{2} [/latex] For fully reversed loading: [latex] \sigma_{\text{min}} = 0 [/latex], so: [latex] \sigma_a = \sigma_m = \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}}{2} [/latex] Step 2: Substitute in Soderberg equation [latex] \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}/2}{\sigma_e} + \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}/2}{\sigma_y} \leq \frac{1}{2} [/latex] Since [latex] \sigma_e = \sigma_y [/latex], both terms are equal: [latex] \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}}{2\sigma_y} + \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}}{2\sigma_y} = \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}}{\sigma_y} [/latex] Step 3: Apply Soderberg Limit [latex] \frac{\sigma_{\text{max}}}{\sigma_y} \leq \frac{1}{2} [/latex] So, [latex] \sigma_{\text{max}} \leq \frac{\sigma_y}{2} [/latex] Step 4: Relate to Endurance Limit Since [latex] \sigma_y = \sigma_e [/latex], [latex] \sigma_{\text{max}} \leq \frac{\sigma_e}{2} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{\text{The maximum applied tensile principal stress is half of the endurance limit}} [/latex] Correct option: (B)

question:
Question 5 The system shown in the figure below consists of a cantilever beam (with flexural
rigidity [latex]EI[/latex] and negligible mass), a spring (with spring constant [latex]K[/latex] and negligible
mass) and a block of mass [latex]m[/latex]. Assuming a lumped parameter model for the system,
the fundamental natural frequency [latex] (\omega_{n}) [/latex] of the system is
solution: Step 1: Stiffness of Cantilever Beam The stiffness of a cantilever beam with flexural rigidity [latex]EI[/latex] and length [latex]L[/latex] is: [latex] k_{\text{beam}} = \frac{3EI}{L^3} [/latex] Step 2: Total Equivalent Stiffness The spring (stiffness [latex]K[/latex]) and the beam act in parallel, so the total stiffness is the sum: [latex] k_{\text{total}} = \frac{3EI}{L^3} + K [/latex] Step 3: Natural Frequency Formula For a lumped mass-spring system, the natural frequency is given by: [latex] \omega_n = \sqrt{\frac{k_{\text{total}}}{m}} [/latex] Substituting the expression for total stiffness: [latex] \omega_n = \sqrt{\frac{\frac{3EI}{L^3} + K}{m}} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{\omega_n = \sqrt{\frac{\frac{3EI}{L^3} + K}{m}}} [/latex] Correct option: (A)

question: Question 6 A metallic square plate is subjected to a uniform hydrostatic pressure ([latex]P[/latex]). Choose the correct Mohr’s circle representing the state of stress at any point in the plate from the options given below. For the Mohr’s circle, normal stress is positive towards right and shear stress is positive in the upward direction.
solution: Concept: In a hydrostatic stress condition, all normal stresses are equal in magnitude and compressive: [latex]\sigma_x = \sigma_y = -P[/latex] and [latex]\tau_{xy} = 0[/latex] Mohr's Circle Representation: Since there is no shear stress and both principal stresses are equal and negative: • The Mohr’s circle reduces to a point at [latex]\sigma = -P[/latex], [latex]\tau = 0[/latex] • Radius of Mohr’s circle = 0 (since [latex]\sigma_1 = \sigma_2 = -P[/latex]) Analysis of Options: (A) Mohr’s circle centered at [latex]P[/latex] -> Incorrect, hydrostatic pressure causes compressive stress ([latex]-P[/latex]) (B) Mohr’s circle centered at [latex]-P[/latex] with radius zero (a point) -> Correct (C) Circle with endpoints at [latex]-P[/latex] and [latex]P[/latex] -> Incorrect, implies unequal principal stresses (D) Circle with center at [latex]0[/latex], radius [latex]P[/latex] -> Incorrect

question: Question 7 The yield stress of a metal in uniaxial tension is 200 MPa. According to von Mises yield criterion, the yield stress (in MPa) of the metal in pure shear is closest to
solution: Given: The yield stress in uniaxial tension is [latex] 200, \text{MPa} [/latex]. We are to find the yield stress in pure shear according to the von Mises yield criterion. Step 1: Von Mises Yield Criterion in Terms of Shear The von Mises criterion relates the equivalent stress in a general stress state to the yield stress in uniaxial tension as: [latex] \sigma_{\text{eq}} = \sqrt{\frac{3}{2} , \boldsymbol{s} : \boldsymbol{s}} [/latex] In pure shear, the equivalent von Mises stress is: [latex] \sigma_{\text{eq}} = \sqrt{3} , \tau [/latex] where [latex] \tau [/latex] is the shear stress. Step 2: Set Equivalent Stress Equal to Yield Stress According to the von Mises criterion: [latex] \sqrt{3} , \tau = 200 [/latex] Step 3: Solve for [latex] \tau [/latex] [latex] \tau = \frac{200}{\sqrt{3}} \approx \frac{200}{1.732} \approx 115.47, \text{MPa} [/latex]

Question 10 A horizontal beam of length [latex]1200 \mathrm{~mm}[/latex] is pinned at the left end and is resting on a roller at the other end as shown in the figure. A linearly varying distributed load is applied on the beam. The magnitude of maximum bending moment acting on the beam is _____ N.m. (round off to 1 decimal place).
solution: Net load, [latex]\mathrm{W}=1 / 2 \times 100 \times 1.2=60 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [latex]\sum \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{A}}=0[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}} \times 1.2-60 \times 0.8=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}}=\frac{60 \times 0.8}{1.2}=\frac{60 \times 2}{3}=40 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [latex]\sum \mathrm{F}_{\mathrm{V}}=0[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{A}}+\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{B}}=60[/latex] [latex]\mathrm{R}_{\mathrm{A}}=20 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [latex]B M[/latex] at a distance ' [latex]x[/latex] ' from end [latex](A)=M_{x}[/latex] [latex]M_{x}=\left[R_{A} \times x-\frac{1}{2} \times\left(\frac{100}{1.2} x\right) \times x\right] \times \frac{x}{3}[/latex] [latex]M_{x}=20 x-\frac{100}{7.2} x^{3}[/latex] For [latex]M_{x}[/latex] to be max., [latex]\frac{\mathrm{dM} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{dx}}=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow 20-\frac{3 \times 100 x^{2}}{7.2}=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow x=\sqrt{\frac{20 \times 7.2}{300}}=0.6928 \mathrm{~m}[/latex] [latex]M_{\text {max }}=20(0.6928)-\frac{100}{7.2}(0.6928)^{3}=9.2376 \mathrm{Nm}[/latex]

question: Question 11 Which of the following beam(s) is/are statically indeterminate?
solution:
Statically indeterminate structures are those structures that cannot be analyzed using statics or equations of equilibrium. In such cases, the number unknowns exceeds the number of equilibrium equation available. Checking each option: For option (A), Number of unknown=2 Number of equilibrium equation=2 For option (B), Number of unknown=2 Number of equilibrium equation=2 For option (C), Number of unknown=3 Number of equilibrium equation=2 For option (D), Number of unknown=3 Number of equilibrium equation=3 So, (C) is statically indeterminate structures.
Note: Official answer key has been given as option (C) and (D), which can be challenged by students.

Question 14 Ignoring the small elastic region, the true stress  [latex](\sigma) -  [/latex] true strain [latex]( \varepsilon)  [/latex] variation of a
material beyond yielding follows the equation [latex]\sigma =400 \varepsilon ^{0.3}  [/latex] MPa. The engineering
ultimate tensile strength value of this material is ________ MPa.
(Rounded off to one decimal place)
solution:
Given [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{\mathrm{T}} & =400 \varepsilon^{0.3}=400 \varepsilon_{\mathrm{T}}^{0.3} \;\;\;...(i)\\
\varepsilon & =\text { true strain }=\varepsilon_{\mathrm{T}} \\
\mathrm{n} & =0.3=\text { strain hardening exponent }
\end{aligned}
[/latex] The true strain [latex]\left(\varepsilon_{T}\right)[/latex] at the onset of necking equal to the strain hardening exponent i.e. at ultimate tensile point. So, [latex]\quad \varepsilon_{\mathrm{T}}=\mathrm{n}=0.3[/latex] at ultimate point So, from equation (i) [latex]
\sigma_{\mathrm{T}}  =400 \times(0.3)^{0.3} =278.74 \mathrm{MPa} \text { at ultimate point }
[/latex] As

[latex]
\varepsilon_{\mathrm{T}}=\ln (1+\varepsilon)
[/latex] So,

[latex]
\varepsilon=\mathrm{e}^{\varepsilon} \mathrm{T}-1=\mathrm{e}^{0.3}-1=0.35
[/latex] and

[latex]
\sigma_{\mathrm{T}}=\sigma(1+\varepsilon)
[/latex] So

[latex]
\sigma_{\text {ultimate }}=\frac{\sigma_{T}}{1+\varepsilon}+\frac{278.74}{1+0.35}=206.55 \mathrm{MPa}
[/latex]

Question 15 Cylindrical bars P and Q have identical lengths and radii, but are composed of
different linear elastic materials. The Young's modulus and coefficient of thermal
expansion of Q are twice the corresponding values of P. Assume the bars to be
perfectly bonded at the interface, and their weights to be negligible. The bars are held between rigid supports as shown in the figure and the
temperature is raised by [latex]\Delta T[/latex]. Assume that the stress in each bar is homogeneous
and uniaxial. Denote the magnitudes of stress in P and Q by [latex]\sigma _1[/latex] and [latex]\sigma _2[/latex],
respectively. Which of the statement(s) given is/are CORRECT?

options.A: The interface between P and Q moves to the left after heating
options.B: The interface between P and Q moves to the right after heating

solution:
Given:
    
[latex]
\alpha_{Q}=2 \alpha_{P}
[/latex] Given [latex]\ell_{1}=\ell_{2}=\beta \ell [/latex] [latex]E=[/latex] young's modulus Change in temperature [latex]=\Delta \mathrm{T}[/latex] where [latex]A=[/latex] cross sectional area of bar and is same for both due to same radii. So, [latex]\sigma_{1}=\sigma_{2}[/latex] Deformation in [latex]\mathrm{P}=\ell \alpha \Delta \mathrm{T}-\frac{\mathrm{P} \ell}{\mathrm{AE}}=\Delta_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex] Deformation in [latex]\mathrm{Q}=2 \alpha \ell \Delta \mathrm{T}-\frac{\mathrm{P} \ell}{2 \mathrm{AE}}=\Delta_{\mathrm{Q}}[/latex] [latex]\Delta_{\mathrm{Q}} \gt \Delta_{\mathrm{P}}[/latex]

question:
Question 19 The principal stresses at a point P in a solid are 70 MPa, -70 MPa and 0. The
yield stress of the material is 100 MPa. Which prediction(s) about material failure
at P is/are CORRECT?

options.A: Maximum normal stress theory predicts that the material fails
options.B: Maximum shear stress theory predicts that the material fails
options.C: Maximum normal stress theory predicts that the material does not fail
options.D: Maximum shear stress theory predicts that the material does not fail

solution:
[latex]\sigma _1=70MPa, \sigma _2= -70MPa, \sigma _3=0 , S_{yt}=100MPa[/latex] For maximum shear stress theory: [latex]\frac{\sigma _1-\sigma _2 }{2}=\frac{70-(-70)}{2}=70[/latex] and [latex]\frac{S_{yt} }{2}=\frac{100}{2}=50[/latex] i.e.  [latex]\frac{\sigma _1-\sigma _2 }{2} \gt \frac{S_{yt} }{2}[/latex] So material will fail
As per maximum normal stress theory: [latex]\sigma _1 \; and \; sigma _2  \gt  sigma _{yt}[/latex] then material will fail Here 70 & -70 < 100 So material is safe.

solution: If bending stress at every fibre is equal to yield strength of the material, then entire cross-section undergoes plastic bending. Then, option ( C ) is correct. If bending stress at inner fibre is less than yield strength and bending stress at extreme fibres is equal to yield strngth, Then, option ( D ) is correct.

question:
Question 22 A rigid beam AD of length 3a = 6 m is hinged at
frictionless pin joint A and supported by two strings
as shown in the figure. String BC passes over two
small frictionless pulleys of negligible radius. All
the strings are made of the same material and have
equal cross-sectional area. A force F = 9 kN is
applied at C and the resulting stresses in the strings
are within linear elastic limit. The self-weight of the
beam is negligible with respect to the applied load.
Assuming small deflections, the tension developed
in the string at C is _________ kN (round off to 2
decimal places).
solution:
F.B.D of beam [latex] \begin{aligned}
\delta l_1:\delta l_2:\delta l_3&=T_1:T_2:T_3\\
1:2:3&=T_1:T_2:T_3\\
\text{Let }T_1&=T\\
\therefore \; T_2&=2T,T_3=3T\\
\Sigma M_A&=0\\
\therefore \; -T \times a-2T &\times 2a-3T \times 3a+F \times 2a=0\\
\therefore \;\; F \times 2a &=14 Ta\\
2F&=14T\\
T&=\frac{F}{7}=\frac{9}{7}kN\\
T_2&=2T=\frac{18}{7}=2.57kN
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 A linear elastic structure under plane stress condition
is subjected to two sets of loading, I and II. The
resulting states of stress at a point corresponding
to these two loadings are as shown in the figure
below. If these two sets of loading are applied
simultaneously, then the net normal component of
stress [latex] \sigma _{xx} [/latex] is ________.
solution:
[latex] \sigma _x=0,\sigma _y=0,\tau _{xy}=0,\theta =-45^{\circ}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
 \sigma _{xx}&=\sigma +\sigma _\theta  \\ 
 \sigma _\theta&=\left [ \frac{\sigma _x +\sigma _y}{2} \right ] +\left [ \frac{\sigma _x -\sigma _y}{2} \right ] \cos 2\theta +\tau _{xy} \sin 2\theta \\ 
 \sigma _\theta &= \frac{0+\sigma }{2} +\left [\frac{0-\sigma }{2}  \right ] \cos 2(-45)+0\\ 
 \sigma _\theta &= \frac{\sigma }{2}\\ 
\sigma _{xx} &=\sigma +\sigma _\theta =\sigma +\frac{\sigma }{2}=\frac{3\sigma }{2} 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 24 Which one of the following is the definition of
ultimate tensile strength (UTS) obtained from a
stress-strain test on a metal specimen?

options.A: Stress value where the stress-strain curve transitions from elastic to plastic behavior
options.B: The maximum load attained divided by the original cross-sectional area
options.C: The maximum load attained divided by the corresponding instantaneous crosssectional area

solution:
Tensile Strength: The tensile strength, or ultimate
tensile strength (UTS), is the maximum load
obtained in a tensile test, divided by the original
cross-sectional area of the specimen. [latex]\sigma _u=\frac{P_{max}}{A_o} [/latex] where, [latex]\sigma _u=[/latex] Ultimate tensile strength, [latex]kg/mm^2[/latex] [latex]P_{max}=[/latex]  Maximum load obtained in a tensile test, kg [latex]A_o=[/latex]  Original cross-sectional area of gauge length
of the test piece, [latex]mm^2[/latex] The tensile strength is a very familiar property and
widely used for identification of a material. It is
very easy to determine and is a quite reproducible
property. It is used for the purposes of specifications
and for quality control of a product. Tensile strength
can be empirically correlated to other properties
such as hardness and fatigue strength. For brittle
materials, the tensile strength is a valid criterion for
design.

question:
Question 25 A thin-walled cylindrical pressure vessel has mean
wall thickness of [latex]t[/latex] and nominal radius of [latex]r[/latex]. The
Poisson's ratio of the wall material is 1/3. When it
was subjected to some internal pressure, its nominal
perimeter in the cylindrical portion increased by
0.1% and the corresponding wall thickness became
[latex]\bar{t}[/latex]. The corresponding change in the wall thickness
of the cylindrical portion, i.e. [latex]100\times (\bar{t}-t)/t[/latex], is
________%(round off to 3 decimal places).
solution:
[latex] \pi(d+\delta d)=1.001 \pi d[/latex] [latex] \varepsilon _1=\frac{\delta d}{d}=0.001=\frac{Pd}{4tE}(2-v)[/latex] [latex] \frac{Pd}{4tE}=\frac{0.001}{(2-v)}=6 \times 10^{-4}[/latex] Radial strain [latex] \varepsilon _2=\frac{\delta t}{t}=\frac{1}{E}\left [ \sigma _r-v(\sigma _h-\sigma _L) \right ][/latex] [latex] \frac{\delta t}{t}=\frac{1}{E}\left [ -v\frac{Pd}{4t}(2+1) \right ][/latex] [latex] \frac{\delta t}{t}=-\frac{Pd}{4tE}v(3)=-6 \times 10^{-4} \times \frac{1}{3}(3)=-6 \times 10^{-4}[/latex] Therefore,
The corresponding change in the wall thickness of
the cylindrical portion [latex] =100 \times \left [ \frac{\bar{t}-t}{t} \right ]=100 \times \frac{\delta t}{t}=100 \times (-6) \times 10^{-4}=-0.06 \%[/latex]

question:
Question 26 An L-shaped elastic member ABC with slender
arms AB and BC of uniform cross-section is
clamped at end A and connected to a pin at end C.
The pin remains in continuous contact with and is
constrained to move in a smooth horizontal slot.
The section modulus of the member is same in both
the arms. The end C is subjected to a horizontal
force P and all the deflections are in the plane of the
figure. Given the length AB is [latex]4a[/latex] and length BC is
[latex]a[/latex], the magnitude and direction of the normal force
on the pin from the slot, respectively, are
solution:
No vertical deflection allowed [latex] \delta _{VC}=\delta _{VB}=0 \text{   (Vertical deflection) }[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
\delta _B&=\frac{ML^2}{2EI}-\frac{NL^2}{3EI}=0\\
\frac{M}{2}&\frac{NL}{3}\\
N&=\frac{3M}{2L}\;\;(\because L=4a)\\
N&=\frac{3Pa}{2 \times 4 a}\\
N&=\frac{3}{8}P \text{   (downward)}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 27 Assuming the material considered in each statement
is homogeneous, isotropic, linear elastic, and the
deformations are in the elastic range, which one or
more of the following statement(s) is/are TRUE?

options.A:
A body subjected to hydrostatic pressure has
no shear stress
options.B:
If a long solid steel rod is subjected to tensile
load, then its volume increases.
options.C:
Maximum shear stress theory is suitable for
failure analysis of brittle materials.
options.D:
If a portion of a beam has zero shear force,
then the corresponding portion of the elastic
curve of the beam is always straight.

solution:
(c) Wrong : Maximum shear stress theory good for
ductile material. (d) If shear force = 0, M = C, But elastic curve is always
non-linear.

question:
Question 28 A uniform light slender beam AB of section modulus
EI is pinned by a frictionless joint A to the ground
and supported by a light inextensible cable CB to
hang a weight W as shown. If the maximum value
of W to avoid buckling of the beam AB is obtained
as [latex]\beta \pi ^2 EI[/latex], where [latex] \pi [/latex] is the ratio of circumference to
diameter of a circle, then the value of [latex]\beta [/latex] is
solution: Draw FBD of AB [latex] \Sigma M_A=0[/latex] [latex]W \times 2.5=T \sin 30^{\circ} \times 2.5 [/latex] [latex] T=2W[/latex] Compressive load acting on AB [latex]=T \cos 30^{\circ}=2W \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=\sqrt{3}W [/latex] Buckling happens when [latex] \sqrt{3}W=P_{cr}=\frac{\pi ^2 EI}{L_e^2}[/latex] [latex] \sqrt{3}W=\frac{\pi ^2 EI}{L^2} \;\;(\because L_e=L \text{as both ends hinged})[/latex] [latex] W=\frac{1 \times \pi ^2 EI}{\sqrt{3} \times (2.5)^2}=0.0924 \pi^2 EI[/latex] [latex]W0.0924 \pi^2 EI=\beta  \pi ^2 EI [/latex] [latex]\beta  =0.0924 m^{-2} [/latex]

question: Question 29 A cantilever beam with a uniform flexural rigidity [latex](EI = 200 \times 10^6 N.m^2)[/latex] is loaded with a concentrated force at its free end. The area of the bending moment diagram corresponding to the full length of the beam is [latex]10000 \;N.m^2[/latex]. The magnitude of the slope of the beam at its free end is  ________micro radian (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: Assume: [latex] \begin{aligned} &A=10000 \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{m}^{2}\\ &\mathrm{El}=200 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~N}-\mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] As per moment area first theorem. [latex] \begin{aligned} \theta_{\mathrm{B}}-\theta_{A} &=\left(\frac{A}{E I}\right) A B \\ \theta_{\mathrm{B}}-0 &=\frac{10000}{200 \times 10^{6}}=0.5 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{radian} \\ \theta_{\mathrm{B}} &=50 \mu \text { radians } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 30 A plane frame PQR (fixed at P and free at R) is shown in the figure. Both members (PQ and QR) have length, L, and flexural rigidity, EI. Neglecting the effect of axial stress and transverse shear, the horizontal deflection at free end, R, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} U&=U_{P Q}+U_{Q P} \\ U&=\frac{M^{2} L}{2 E I}+\int_{0}^{L} \frac{\left(M_{x-x}\right)^{2}(d x)}{2 E I} \\ U&=\frac{(F L)^{2} L}{2 E I}+\int_{0}^{L}\left(\frac{(F x)^{2}(d x)}{2 E I}\right) \\ U&=\frac{F^{2} L^{3}}{2 E I}+\frac{F^{2} L^{3}}{6 E I}=\frac{2 F^{2} L^{3}}{3 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex] By Castigliano's theorem: [latex] \left(\delta_{H}\right)_{R}=\frac{\partial U}{\partial F}=\frac{4 F L^{3}}{3 E I}[/latex]

question: Question 31 A steel cubic block of side 200 mm is subjected to hydrostatic pressure of [latex]250 N/mm^2[/latex]. The elastic modulus is [latex]2 \times 10^5 \; N/mm^2[/latex] and Poisson ratio is 0.3 for steel. The side of the block is reduced by  _____mm (round off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=200 \mathrm{GPa} \\ \sigma &=250 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \mu &=0.3 \\ \epsilon_{x} &=\epsilon_{y}=\epsilon_{z}=\frac{\delta a}{a} \\ \frac{1}{E}\left[\sigma_{x}-\mu\left(\sigma_{y}+\sigma_{z}\right)\right] &=\frac{(\delta a)}{a} \\ \left(\frac{-\sigma}{E}\right)(1-2 \mu)&=\frac{\delta a}{a}\\ \delta a &=-\frac{(250)(1-0.6)(200)}{200 \times 10^{3}} \\ \delta a &=(-) 0.10 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Reduction in side of cube is 0.10mm.

question: Question 32 A column with one end fixed and one end free has a critical buckling load of 100 N. For the same column, if the free end is replaced with a pinned end then the critical buckling load will be  ________N (round off to the nearest integer).
solution: For a given material in 0.1 and length, [latex] \mathrm{Pe} \propto \frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}[/latex] where, [latex]\quad \alpha=[/latex] length fixity coefficient Pe= Buckling or critical load. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{(P e)_{I I}}{(P e)_{I}} &=\left(\frac{\alpha_{I}}{\alpha_{I I}}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{2 L}{1 / \sqrt{2}}\right)^{2}=8 \\ \left(P_{e}\right)_{I I} &=8\left(P_{e}\right)_{I}=800 \mathrm{~N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 33 An overhanging beam PQR is subjected to uniformly distributed load 20 kN/m as shown in the figure. The maximum bending stress  developed in the  beam is  ________MPa (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{D}-M_{A} &=\frac{1}{2} \times 15 \times 0.75  \\ M_{D} &=5.625 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m}(\mathrm{s}) \\ \Sigma M_{A}&=60 \times 1.5-R_{B} \times 2=0  \\ R_{B} &=45 \mathrm{kN}(\uparrow) ; \quad R_{A}=15 \mathrm{kN}(\uparrow) \end{aligned}[/latex] Location of D: [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{15}{x} &=\frac{25}{2-x} \\ 6-3 x &=5 x \\ &=\frac{3}{4} m \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} M_C-M_B &=\frac{1}{2} \times 20 \times 1 \\ M_B&=-10 kN- m \\ M_B &= 10kN - m \;(+1)\\ \text{Max B.M.}&=\text{Larger of }(M_B \text{ and } M_D) \\ M_B&=10kN- m\; (+1) \\ (\sigma _b)_{max} &=\frac{M_{max}}{Z_{N.A.}}\\&=\frac{6 \times 10 \times 10^6}{224 \times 100^2}=250MPa \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 A right solid circular cone standing on its base on a horizontal surface is of height H and base radius R. The cone is made of a material with specific weight w and elastic modulus E. The vertical deflection at the mid-height of the cone due to self-weight is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{\mathrm{x}-\mathrm{x}}&=\frac{(-) \mathrm{W} A_{x-x}(x)}{3}\\ \text{Contraction of small strip }&=(\delta l)_{\text {strip }}\\ &=\frac{P_{x-x} d x}{(A E)_{x-x}} \\ &=\frac{w\left(A_{x-x}\right)(x) d x}{3\left(A_{x-x}\right) E}=\frac{w x}{3 E} d x \end{aligned}[/latex] Contraction of conical bar at mid height ( i.e. [latex]x=\frac{H}{2}[/latex] ) [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\int_{H / 2}^{H}(\delta l)_{\operatorname{stn} p} \\ &=\frac{W}{3 E} \int_{H / 2}^{H} x d x \\ &=\frac{w}{6 E}\left[H^{2}-\frac{H^{2}}{4}\right]=\frac{w H^{2}}{8 E} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 A prismatic bar PQRST is subjected to axial loads as shown in the figure. The segments having maximum and minimum axial stresses, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{\max }&=P_{S T}=25 \mathrm{kN} \\ P_{\min }&=P_{R S}=5 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, maximum and minimum axial stresses are in ST and RS portions because of prismatic bar.

question: Question 36 A cantilever beam of length, [latex]L[/latex], and flexural rigidity, [latex]EI[/latex], is subjected to an end moment, [latex]M[/latex], as shown in the figure. The deflection of the beam at [latex]x=\frac{L}{2}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y_{C}-Y_{A}&=\left(\frac{A \bar{X}}{E I}\right)_{A C} \\ Y_{C}-0&=\frac{1}{E I}\left[\frac{-ML}{2} \times \frac{L}{4}\right]\\ Y_{C}&=\frac{ML^{2}}{8 E I} \text { (downward) } \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The loading and unloading response of a metal is shown in the figure. The elastic and plastic strains corresponding to 200 MPa stress, respectively, are
solution: Elastic strain : Which can be recovered [latex]= 0.03 - 0.01 = 0.02[/latex] Plastic strain : Permanent strain [latex]= 0.01 [/latex]

question:
Question 38 Uniaxial compression test data for a solid metal bar of length 1 m is shown in the figure. The bar material has a linear elastic response from O to P followed by a non-linear
response. The point P represents the yield point of the material. The rod is pinned at
both the ends. The minimum diameter of the bar so that it does not buckle under axial
loading before reaching the yield point is _______ mm (round off to one decimal place).
solution: For both end pin, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{L^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2} E A \cdot \frac{d^{2}}{16}}{L^{2}} \\ \frac{P}{A E} &=\frac{\pi^{2} d^{2}}{16 L^{2}} \\ \varepsilon_{y} &=\frac{\pi^{2} d^{2}}{16 L^{2}} \\ d &=\sqrt{\frac{16 L^{2} \varepsilon_{y}}{\pi^{2}}} \\ &=\sqrt{\frac{16 \times 1000^{2} \times 0.002}{\pi^{2}}} \\ &=56.94 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 39 A thin-walled cylinder of radius [latex]r[/latex] and thickness [latex]t[/latex] is open at both ends, and fits snugly
between two rigid walls under ambient conditions, as shown in the figure. The material of the cylinder has Young's modulus E, Poisson's ratio v, and coefficient
of thermal expansion [latex]\alpha[/latex]. What is the minimum rise in temperature [latex]\Delta T[/latex] of the cylinder
(assume uniform cylinder temperature with no buckling of the cylinder) required to prevent
gas leakage if the cylinder has to store the gas at an internal pressure of [latex]p[/latex] above the
atmosphere?
solution: since cylinder is open at both end. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \qquad \sigma_{L}&=0\\ \text{For no leakage,} \quad \varepsilon_{L_{P_{r}}}&=\varepsilon_{L_{\text {temp }}} \\ \frac{v \sigma_{n}}{E} &=\alpha \Delta T \\ \frac{v P r}{t E} &=\alpha \Delta T \\ \Delta T &=\frac{v p r}{\alpha t E} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 40 A cantilever of length [latex]l[/latex], and flexural rigidity EI, stiffened by a spring of stiffness k, is
loaded by transverse force P, as shown The transverse deflection under the load is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta_{\text {beam }} &=\Delta_{\text {spring }} \\ \frac{(P-R) l^{3}}{3 E I} &=\frac{R}{k} \\ P-R &=\frac{3 E I}{K l^{3}} R \\ \therefore \quad R &=\frac{P}{1+\frac{3 E I}{K l^{3}}}=\frac{P l^{3} K}{K l^{3}+3 E I} \\ \therefore \quad \Delta_{\text {beam }} &=\frac{R}{K}=\frac{P l^{3}}{3 E I+K l^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 41 A beam of negligible mass is hinged at support P and has a roller support Q as shown
in the figure. A point load of 1200 N is applied at point R. The magnitude of the reaction force at
support Q is __________ N.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma \vec{M}_{P} &=0 \\ 1200 \times 5-R_{Q} \times 4 &=0 \\ R_{Q} &=\frac{1200 \times 5}{4}=1500 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{B_{\text {Right }}} &=0 \\ 4 R_{C} &=10 \times 4 \times 2 \\ R_{C} &=20 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 43 The barrier shown between two water tanks of unit width (1 m) into the plane of the screen
is modeled as a cantilever. Taking the density of water as 1000 [latex]kg/m^3[/latex], and the acceleration due to gravity as 10 [latex]m/s^2[/latex],
the maximum absolute bending moment developed in the cantilever is ______ kNm
(round off to the nearest integer).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F_{1} &=\rho g A \cdot \bar{x}_{1} \\ &=1000 \times 10 \times(1 \times 4) \times 2=80 \mathrm{kN}\\ F_{2} &=\rho g A \cdot \bar{x}_{2} \\ &=1000 \times 10 \times(1 \times 1) \times 0.5=5 \mathrm{kN} \\ C P_{1} &=4 \times \frac{1}{3}=\frac{4}{3} \mathrm{m} \\ C P_{2} &=1 \times \frac{1}{3}=\frac{1}{3} \mathrm{m} \\ M_{A} &=80 \times \frac{4}{3}-5 \times \frac{1}{3}=105 \mathrm{kN}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 The truss shown in the figure has four members of length [latex]l[/latex] and flexural rigidity EI, and
one member of length [latex]l\sqrt{2}[/latex] and flexural rigidity 4EI. The truss is loaded by a pair of
forces of magnitude P, as shown in the figure. The smallest value of P, at which any of the truss members will buckle is
solution:
Since buckling will happen due to compression,
and it occurs in diagonal only [latex]R_{BD}\geq \frac{\pi ^2 EI}{L^2} [/latex] [latex]P\geq \frac{\pi ^2 (4EI)}{(\sqrt{2}L)^2} [/latex] [latex]P\geq \frac{2\pi ^2 EI}{L^2}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 Bars of square and circular cross-section with 0.5 m length are made of a material with
shear strength of 20 MPa. The square bar cross-section dimension is 4 cm x 4 cm and
the cylindrical bar cross-section diameter is 4 cm. The specimens are loaded as shown
in the figure. Which specimen(s) will fail due to the applied load as per maximum shear stress theory?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma &=\frac{80 \times 10^{3}}{40^{2}}=50 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \tau_{\max } &=\frac{\sigma}{2}=25 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \gt 20 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \tau_{\max } &=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}}=\frac{16 \times 64 \pi \times 10^{3}}{\pi(40)^{3}} \\ &=16 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \lt 20 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma &=\frac{320 \times 10^{3}}{40^{3}}=30 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ 6 &=\frac{\sigma}{2}=15 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \lt 20 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \tau_{\max } &=\frac{\sigma}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 46 The stress state at a point in a material under plane stress condition is equi-biaxial tension
with a magnitude of 10 MPa. If one unit on the [latex]\sigma -\tau[/latex] plane is 1 MPa, the Mohr's circle representation of the state-of-stress is given by

options.A:
a circle with a radius equal to principal stress and its center at the origin of the
[latex]\sigma -\tau[/latex] plane
options.B: a point on the [latex]\sigma[/latex] axis at a distance of 10 units from the origin
options.C: a circle with a radius of 10 units on the [latex]\sigma -\tau[/latex] plane
options.D: a point on the [latex]\tau[/latex] axis at a distance of 10 units from the origin

solution:
The given state of stress is represented by a point on
[latex]\sigma -\tau[/latex] graph which is located on [latex]\sigma[/latex]-axis at a distance

question: Question 47 A horizontal cantilever beam of circular cross-section, length 1.0 m and flexural rigidity EI= 200 [latex]N\cdot m^2[/latex] is subjected to an applied moment MA= 1.0 [latex]N\cdot m[/latex] at the free end as shown in the figure. The magnitude of the vertical deflection of the free end is _______mm (round off to one decimal place).
solution: Deflection at free and [latex]y_{B}=\frac{M_{A} L^{2}}{2 E I} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad=\frac{1 \times 1^{2}}{2 \times 200}=2.5 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m} \\ \therefore y_{B}=2.5 \times 10^{-3} \times 10^{3} \mathrm{mm}=2.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \quad y_{B}=2.5 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 48 A prismatic, straight, elastic, cantilever beam is subjected to a linearly distributed transverse load as shown below. If the beam length is L, Young's modulus E, and area moment of inertia I, the magnitude of the maximum deflection is
solution: Double Integration method: Let x be distance from the free end [latex] \begin{aligned} \mathrm{M}_{\mathrm{x}} &=-\left(\frac{1}{2} \times \mathrm{x} \times \frac{\mathrm{q} \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{L}}\right)\left(\frac{\mathrm{x}}{3}\right) \\ &=-\frac{\mathrm{q} \mathrm{x}^{3}}{6 \mathrm{L}} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{EI} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}^{2} \mathrm{y}}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}}=-\left(\frac{\mathrm{qx}^{3}}{6 \mathrm{L}}\right)[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{EI} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{y}}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{x}}=-\frac{\mathrm{q} \mathrm{x}^{4}}{24 \mathrm{L}}+\mathrm{C}_{1} \rightarrow  \text{Slope equation} \;\; ...(1) [/latex] [latex] \text {EI.y }=-\frac{\mathrm{q} \mathrm{x}^{5}}{120 \mathrm{L}}+\mathrm{C}_{1} \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{C}_{2} \rightarrow \text { Deflection equation }\; \; ...(2)[/latex] Boundary Conditions: (a) Fixed end, [latex]\mathrm{x}=\mathrm{L}, \theta_{\mathrm{A}}=0 ; \mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{A}}=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \text{from }(1) [/latex] [latex]0=-\frac{\mathrm{q} \mathrm{L}^{4}}{24 \mathrm{L}}+\mathrm{C}_{1} \Rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{1}=\frac{\mathrm{qL}^{3}}{24} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad \text{from(2) }  [/latex] [latex] 0=-\frac{\mathrm{qL}^{5}}{120 \mathrm{L}}+\frac{\mathrm{qL}^{3}}{2 \mathrm{L}}(\mathrm{L})+\mathrm{C}_{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \mathrm{C}_{2}=\frac{\mathrm{qL}^{4}}{30}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] maximum deflection at free end i.e. at [latex]\mathrm{x}=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \mathrm{y}_{\max }=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{2}}{\mathrm{EI}}=\frac{\mathrm{qL}^{4}}{30 \mathrm{EI}}[/latex]

question:
Question 49 Consider two concentric circular cylinders of different materials M and N in contact with each other at r=b, as shown below. The interface at r=b is frictionless. The composite cylinder system is subjected to internal pressure P. Let [latex](u_r^M,u_\theta ^M)[/latex]
 and [latex](\sigma_{rr}^M, \sigma_{\theta \theta}^M)[/latex] denote the radial and tangential displacement and stress components, respectively, in material M. Similarly, [latex](u_r^N,u_\theta ^N)[/latex]
 and [latex](\sigma_{rr}^N,\sigma_{\theta \theta}^N)[/latex] denote the radial and tangential displacement and stress components, respectively, in material N. The boundary conditions that need to be satisfied at the frictionless interface between the two cylinders are:
solution:
As the contact is frictionless, one cylinder can rotate freely with respect other. The displacement in 
tangential directions need not be same at a point contact for two cylinders (i.e., [latex] u_{\theta}^{M} \neq u_{\theta}^{N} [/latex] ). Similarly the Hoop stress at point of contact need not be same (i.e., [latex] \sigma_{\theta \theta}^{M} \neq \sigma_{\theta \theta}^{N} [/latex] ). As the interface will be always 
in contact the displacement in radial direction and stress in radial directions must be same for two 
cylinders. i.e., [latex] u_{r}^{M}=u_{r}^{N} [/latex] and [latex] \sigma_{r}^{M}=\sigma_{r r}^{N} [/latex]

question: Question 50 A wire of circular cross-section ofdiameter 1.0 mm is bent into a circular arc of radius 1.0 m by application of pure bending moments at its ends. The Young's modulus of the material of the wire is 100 GPa. The maximum tensile stress developed in the wire is ______MPa.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\mathrm{d}=1.0 \mathrm{mm}\\ &\mathrm{y}_{\max }=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{2}=\frac{1.0}{2}=0.5 \mathrm{mm}\\ &\mathrm{R}=1.0 \mathrm{m}=1000 \mathrm{mm}\\ &\mathrm{E}=100 \mathrm{GPa}=100 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{MPa}\\ &\text { From bending equation, } \frac{\mathrm{f}_{\max }}{\mathrm{y}_{\max }}=\frac{\mathrm{E}}{\mathrm{R}}\\ &\mathrm{f}_{\max }=\mathrm{y}_{\max } \cdot \frac{\mathrm{E}}{\mathrm{R}}\\ &=0.5 \times \frac{100 \times 10^{3}}{1000}=50 \mathrm{MPa}\\ &\therefore \mathrm{f}_{\max }=50 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 The state of stress at a point in a component isrepresented by a Mohr's circle of radius 100MPa centered at 200 MPa on the normal stress axis. On a plane passing through the same point, the normal stress is 260 MPa. The magnitude of the shear stress on the same plane at the same point is ______ MPa.
solution: In triangle CEF [latex] \begin{array}{l} \mathrm{CF}^{2}=\mathrm{CE}^{2}+\mathrm{EF}^{2} \\ 100^{2}=60^{2}=\mathrm{EF}^{2}\\ \mathrm{EF}^{2}=100^{2}-60^{2}=6400 \\ \mathrm{EF}=80 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \mathrm{EF} \rightarrow [/latex]Represents shear stress at the same point [latex]=\mathrm{EF}=\tau=80 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 52 Consider a linear elastic rectangular thin sheet of metal, subjected to uniform uniaxial tensile stress of 100 MPa along the length direction. Assume plane stress conditions in the plane normal to the thickness. The Young's modulus E=200 MPa and Poisson's ratio v=0.3 are given. The principal strains in the plane of the sheet are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{\mathrm{x}}&=100 \mathrm{MPa} \\ v&=\mu=0.3 \\ \sigma_{\mathrm{y}}&=0, \sigma_{\mathrm{z}}=0, \mathrm{E}=200 \mathrm{MPa} \\ &\text { Principal strain in x-direction } \\ &=\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{\mathrm{x}}=\frac{\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{E}}-\mu \frac{\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}}{\mathrm{E}} \\ &=\frac{100}{200}-0=0.5\\ &\text { Principal strain in y-direction } \\ &=\epsilon_{2}=\epsilon_{\mathrm{y}}=\frac{\sigma_{\mathrm{y}}}{\mathrm{E}}-\mu \frac{\sigma_{\mathrm{x}}}{\mathrm{E}}\\ &=0-(0.3)\left(\frac{100}{200}\right)=-0.15\\ &\therefore\left(\epsilon_{\mathrm{x}}, \epsilon_{\mathrm{y}}\right)=(0.5-0.15) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 At a critical point in a component, the state of stress is given as [latex]\sigma _{xx}=100 MPa[/latex], [latex]\sigma _{yy}=220 MPa[/latex], [latex]\sigma _{xy}=\sigma _{yx}=80 MPa[/latex] and all other stress components are zero. The yield strength of the material is 468 MPa. The factor of safety on the basis of maximum shear stress theory is ______ (round off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \sigma_{x}=100 \mathrm{MPa}, \sigma_{y y}=220 \mathrm{MPa}, \tau_{x y}=80 \mathrm{MPa} \\ S_{y t}=468 \mathrm{MPa}, \mathrm{F.S.}=?(\mathrm{MSST}) \\ \sigma_{1, 2}=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\tau_{x y}\right)^{2}} \\ =\frac{100+220}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{100-220}{2}\right)^{2}+80^{2}} \\ \sigma_{1}=257.08 \mathrm{MPa}, \sigma_{2}=62.9 \mathrm{MPa}, \sigma_{3}=0 \end{array}[/latex] According to maximum shear stress theory, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \tau_{\max }=\frac{S_{y t}}{2 \times F S}=\operatorname{Max}\left[\left|\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}\right|,\left|\frac{\sigma_{1}}{2}\right|,\left|\frac{\sigma_{2}}{2}\right|\right]\\ \tau_{\max }=\frac{257.08}{2}=128.54 \mathrm{MPa} \\ 128.54=\frac{468}{2 \times \mathrm{FS}} \\ \mathrm{FS}=1.78 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 54 In a UTM experiment, a sample of length 100 mm, was loaded in tension until failure. The failure load was 40 kN. The displacement, measured using the cross-head motion, at failure, was 15 mm. The compliance of the UTM is constant and is given by [latex]5 \times 10^{-8}[/latex] m/N. The strain at failure in the sample is _______%
solution:
Total Strain [latex]=\frac{\delta L}{L}=\frac{15 \times 100}{100}=15  [/latex] Deformation recoverable at applied failure load [latex]=5 \times 10^{-8} \times 40 \times 10^3 \times 10^3 mm [/latex] [latex]\delta _{recov}=2mm [/latex] Recoverable strain [latex]=\frac{2 \times 100}{100}=2  [/latex] Permanent strain = total strain – recoverable strain
= 15% - 2% = 13%

question: Question 55 Consider a prismatic straight beam of length [latex]L= \pi m[/latex], pinned at the two ends as shown in the figure. The beam has a square cross-section of side p=6 mm. The Young's modulus E= 200 GPa, and the coefficient of thermal expansion [latex]\alpha =3 \times 10^{-6}K^{-1}[/latex]. The minimum temperature rise required to cause Euler buckling of the beam is ________ K.
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \mathrm{L}=\pi \mathrm{m} \\ \text { side }=6 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{E}=200 \mathrm{GPa} \\ \alpha=3 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex] Thermal thrust due to restricted expansion, [latex] P=\left(\sigma_{t h}\right) A=(E \alpha t) A[/latex] Euler buckling load, [latex]P_{e}=\frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{L_{c}^{2}} [/latex] For hinged ends, [latex] \mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{c}}=\mathrm{L} [/latex] [latex] \therefore P e=\frac{\pi^{2} E \frac{a^{4}}{12}}{L^{2}}[/latex] Condition for buckling, [latex]\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{c}} [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{c} (E \alpha t) A=\frac{\pi^{2} E}{L^{2}} \frac{a^{4}}{12} \\ (\alpha t) a^{2}=\frac{\pi^{2} a^{4}}{12 L^{2}} \\ t=\frac{1}{\alpha} \times \frac{\pi^{2} a^{2}}{12 L^{2}} \\ =\frac{1}{3 \times 10^{-6}} \times \frac{\pi^{2} \times 6^{2}}{12(\pi \times 1000)^{2}} \\ \mathrm{t}=1^{\circ} \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 56 Consider an elastic straight beam of length [latex]L=10 \pi m[/latex], with square cross-section of side a=5 mm, and Young's modulus E=200 GPa. This straight beam was bent in such a way that the two ends meet, to form a circle of mean radius R. Assuming that Euler-Bernoulli beam theory is applicable to this bending problem, the maximum tensile bending stress in the bent beam is __________ MPa.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{L}&=10 \pi \mathrm{m} \\ \mathrm{a}&=5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \mathrm{E}&=200 \mathrm{GPa} \\ \text { Length of wire }&=\mathrm{L}=\pi \mathrm{D}=2 \pi \mathrm{R} \\ 10 \pi&=2 \pi \mathrm{R} \\ \mathrm{R}&=5 \mathrm{m}\\  &\text { From bending equation, } \\ \frac{\mathrm{M}}{\mathrm{I}}&=\frac{\mathrm{f}}{\mathrm{Y}}=\frac{\mathrm{E}}{\mathrm{R}}\\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{f}{y}&=\frac{E}{R}\\ \mathrm{f}_{\max }&=\mathrm{y}_{\max } \times \frac{\mathrm{E}}{\mathrm{R}} \\ &=2.5 \times \frac{200 \times 10^{3}}{5 \times 10^{3}}\\ &=100 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 57 A plane-strain compression (forging) of a block is shown in the figure. The strain in the z-direction is zero. The yield strength ([latex]S_y[/latex]) in uniaxial tension/compression of the material of the block is 300 MPa and it follows the Tresca (maximum shear stress) criterion. Assume that the entire block has started yielding. At a point where [latex]\sigma _x=40 MPa[/latex] (compressive) and [latex]\tau _{xy}=0[/latex], the stress component [latex]\sigma _y[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \tau_{x y}=0 \\ \text { Principal Stress, } \sigma_{z}=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2} \\ \therefore \sigma_{x}=\sigma_{\max }, \sigma_{y}=\sigma_{\min } \\ \therefore \sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}=\sigma_{0} \\ -40-\sigma_{y}=300 \\ \Rightarrow \sigma_{y}=-340 \mathrm{MPa}=340 \mathrm{MPa}(\text {Compression}) \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 58 Consider the stress-strain curve for an ideal elastic-plastic strain hardening metal as shown in the figure. The metal was loaded in uniaxial tension starting from O. Upon loading, the stress-strain curve passes through initial yield point at P, and then strain hardens to point Q, where the loading was stopped. From point Q, the specimen was unloaded to point R, where the stress is zero. If the same specimen is reloaded in tension from point R, the value of stress at which the material yields again is _________ MPa.
solution: Yield strength will increase to 210 MPa due to strain hardening.

question: Question 59 A solid cube of side 1 m is kept at a room temperature of 32 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex]. The coefficient of linear thermal expansion of the cube material is [latex]1 \times 10^{-5}/^{\circ}C[/latex] and the bulk modulus is 200 GPa. If the cube is constrained all around and heated uniformly to 42 [latex]^{\circ}C[/latex], then the magnitude of volumetric (mean) stress (in MPa) induced due to heating is____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\therefore \quad \text { Volumetric strain } \epsilon_{\mathrm{v}}=\frac{\sigma}{\mathrm{k}}=3 \alpha(\mathrm{t})\\ &\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \sigma &=3 \alpha \mathrm{t}(\mathrm{k}) \\ &=3 \times 1 \times 10^{-5}(42-32) \times 200 \times 10^{3} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma &=60 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 60 A cylindrical rod of diameter 10 mm and length 1.0 m is fixed at one end. The other end is twisted by an angle of 10[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] by applying a torque. If the maximum shear strain in the rod is [latex]p \times 10^{-3}[/latex], then p is equal to ______ (round off to two decimal places).
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned} &\mathrm{d}=10 \mathrm{mm}\\ &\theta=10^{\circ}=10^{\circ} \times \frac{\pi}{180} \text { radian }\\ &\mathrm{R}=\frac{\mathrm{d}}{2}=5 \mathrm{mm}\\ &\mathrm{L}=1 \mathrm{m}\\ &\phi_{\max }=P \times 10^{-3}\\ &\text { from torsion equation, } \\ \frac{\mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{J}}&=\frac{\tau_{\max }}{\mathrm{R}}=\frac{\mathrm{G} \theta}{\ell}\\ &\Rightarrow \frac{\tau_{\max }}{G}=\frac{R \theta}{\ell}\\ &\phi_{\max }=\frac{R \theta}{\ell} \\ P \times 10^{-3}&=\frac{5 \times 10^{\circ} \times \frac{\pi}{180}}{1000}=0.8726 \times 10^{-3} \\
\therefore \;\;P&=0.8726\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 61 The true stress (in MPa) versus true strain relationship for a metal is given by [latex]\sigma =1020\, \varepsilon^{0.4}[/latex] The cross-sectional area at the start of a test (when the stress and strain values are equal to zero) is 100 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex]. The cross-sectional area at the time of necking (in [latex]mm^{2}[/latex]) is ________
(correct to two decimal places)
solution: Given,[latex]\qquad \sigma=1020 \varepsilon^{0.4}[/latex] at UTS, [latex]\qquad\varepsilon_{T}=n=0.4[/latex] at UTS, neak formation starts, [latex] \begin{aligned} \varepsilon_{T} &=0.4=\ln \left(\frac{A_{0}}{A_{f}}\right) \\ 0.4 &=\ln \left(\frac{100}{A_{f}}\right) \\ \frac{A_{0}}{A_{f}} &=e^{0.4} \\ A_{f} &=\frac{100}{e^{0.4}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Cross-section area at the time of necking, [latex] A_{f}=67.032 \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 62 A bimetallic cylindrical bar of cross sectional area 1 [latex]m^{2}[/latex] is made by bonding Steel  (Young's modulus = 210 GPa)  and Aluminium (Young's modulus = 70 GPa)  as shown in the figure. To maintain tensile axial strain of magnitude [latex]10^{-6}[/latex]  in Steel bar and compressive axial strain of magnitude  [latex]10^{-6}[/latex]  in Aluminum bar, the magnitude of the required force P (in kN) along the indicated direction is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{s t}+P_{A l} &=P \\ \Delta_{\mathrm{st}}+\Delta_{\mathrm{A} 1} &=0 \quad\ldots(i)\\ \frac{P_{s t} \cdot \frac{L}{2}}{A E_{s t}}+\frac{\left(P_{s t}-P\right) \frac{L}{2}}{A E_{A L}} &=0 \\ \frac{P_{s t}}{210}+\frac{P_{s t}-P}{70} &=0 \\ \therefore \quad P_{s t} &=\frac{3 P}{4} \\ \text{Now,}\quad \Delta_{\mathrm{st}} &=\frac{P_{s t \cdot} \frac{L}{2}}{A E_{s t}}\\ \epsilon_{s t}&=\frac{P_{s t}}{A . E_{s t}}=\frac{3 P}{4 A E_{s t}}\\ \therefore\quad P&=\frac{E_{s t} \times 4 A \epsilon_{s t}}{3}\\ &=\frac{10^{-6} \times 4 \times 1 \times 2.10 \times 10^{9}}{3} \\ &=280 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 63 A bar of circular cross section is clamped at ends P and Q as shown in the figure. A
torsional moment T=150 Nm  is applied at a distance of 100 mm from end P. The
torsional reactions [latex]\left ( T_{P}, T_{Q} \right  )[/latex]  in  Nm at the ends P and Q respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{P}+T_{Q} &=T \ldots(i)\\ Q_{P R}+Q_{R Q} &=0 \\ \frac{T_{P} \cdot L}{G I_{P}}+\frac{\left(T_{P}-T\right) 2 L}{G I_{P}} &=0 \\ T_{P}+2 T_{P} &=2 T \\ T_{P} &=\frac{2 T}{3}=100 \mathrm{Nm}\\ \text{From equation (i)}\\ T_{Q}&=\frac{T}{3}=50 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 A hollow circular shaft of inner radius 10 mm, outer radius 20 mm and length 1 m is to be used as a torsional spring. If the shear modulus of the material of the shaft is 150 GPa, the torsional stiffness of the shaft (in kN-m/rad) is ________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\qquad \begin{aligned} \text { Torsional stiffness }&=\frac{G I_{P}}{L} \\ &=\frac{150 \times 10^{9} \times \frac{\pi}{32}\left[0.04^{4}-0.02^{4}\right]}{1} \\ &=35343 \mathrm{Nm} / \mathrm{rad}=35.343 \mathrm{kNm} / \mathrm{rad} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 65 The minimum axial compressive load, P, required to initiate buckling for a pinned-pinned slender column with bending stiffness EI and length L is
solution: For both ends hinged buckling load, [latex]P=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{L^{2}}[/latex]

question: Question 66 A bar is compressed to half of its original length. The magnitude of true strain produced in the deformed bar is _________________ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]L_{0} \rightarrow [/latex] Initial length [latex] \begin{array}{c} L=\frac{L_{0}}{2} \rightarrow \text { Final length } \\ \text { true strain }=\epsilon_{T}=\ln \frac{L}{L_{0}}=\ln \left[\frac{\left(\frac{L_{0}}{2}\right)}{L_{0}}\right]=\ln \frac{1}{2}=-0.693 \end{array}[/latex] As examiner mentioned "magnitude" only magnitude will be given 0.693.

question: Question 67 The true stress ([latex]\sigma[/latex] ) - true strain ([latex]\varepsilon[/latex] ) diagram of a strain hardening material is shown in figure. First, there is loading up to point A, i.e., up to stress of 500 MPa and strain of 0.5. Then from point A, there is unloading up to point B, i.e., to stress of 100 MPa. Given that the Young's modulus E = 200 GPa, the natural strain at point B ( [latex]\varepsilon _{B}[/latex]  ) is _________ (correct to three decimal places).
solution: We know that Slope of AB line is E [latex]\begin{aligned} E &=\frac{A C}{B C} \\ 200 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{MPa} &=\frac{(500-100) \mathrm{MPa}}{B C} \\ B C &=\frac{400}{200 \times 10^{3}}=0.002 \\ \therefore \qquad \epsilon_{E} &=0.5-0.002=0.498 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 A simply supported beam of width 100 mm, height 200 mm and length 4 m is carrying a uniformly distributed load of intensity 10 kN/m. The maximum bending stress (in MPa) in the beam is __________ (correct to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\text { Maximum B.M.. } M=\frac{w L^{2}}{8}=\frac{10 \times 16}{8}=20 \mathrm{kNm} \quad (L=4)[/latex] Maximum Bending Stress [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{\max } &=\frac{M}{I} y_{\max }=\frac{20 \times 10^{3}}{\left(\frac{0.1 \times 0.2^{3}}{12}\right)} \times 0.1 \\ &=30 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}=30 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 A carpenter glues a pair of cylindrical wooden logs by bonding their end faces at an angle of [latex]\theta = 30^{\circ}[/latex] as shown in the figure. The glue used at the interface fails if Criterion 1: the maximum normal stress exceeds 2.5 MPa. Criterion 2: the maximum shear stress exceeds 1.5 MPa. Assume that the interface fails before the logs fail. When a uniform tensile stress of 4 MPa is applied, the interface

options.C: fails because of both criteria 1 and 2

question: Question 70 The state of stress at a point, for a body in plane stress, is shown in the figure below. If the minimum principal stress is 10 kPa, then the normal stress [latex]\sigma_{y}[/latex]   (in kPa) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{x} &=100 \mathrm{kPa}, \tau_{x y}=50 \mathrm{kPa} \\ \text { Minimum principal stress } &=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2}-\sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ 10 &=\frac{100+\sigma_{y}}{2}-\sqrt{\left(\frac{100-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+50^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \sqrt{\left(50-\frac{\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+50^{2}} &=50+\frac{\sigma_{y}}{2}-10=40+\frac{\sigma_{y}}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] By squaring [latex] 2500+\frac{\sigma_{y}^{2}}{4}-50 \sigma_{y}+2500=1600+\frac{\sigma_{y}^{2}}{4}+40 \sigma_{y}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad 90 \sigma_{y} &=3400 \\ \sigma_{y} &=37.78 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 71 A steel column of rectangular section (15 mm x 10 mm) and length 1.5 m is simply supported at both ends. Assuming modulus of elasticity, E = 200 GPa for steel, the critical axial load (in kN) is ____ (correct to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Buckling load } &=\frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{L^{2}} \\&=\frac{\pi^{2} \times 200 \times 10^{3} \times \frac{15 \times 10^{3}}{12}}{1500^{2}}\\&=1096.62 \mathrm{N} \\ &=1.097 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 In a linearly hardening plastic material, the true stress beyond initial yielding

options.A: increases linearly with the true strain
options.B: decreases linearly with the true strain
options.C: first increases linearly and then decreases linearly with the true strain

question: Question 73 For an Oldham coupling used between two shafts, which among the following statements are correct? I. Torsional load is transferred along shaft axis. II. A velocity ratio of 1:2 between shafts is obtained without using gears. III. Bending load is transferred transverse to shaft axis. IV. Rotation is transferred along shaft axis.
solution: Oldham coupling is used to connect two shafts which are not on the same axis means they are not aligned to the same axis So, (1) Torsional load is transferred along shaft axis as both shafts are rotating member. So, that statement is correct. (2) A velocity ratio 1:1 between shafts is obtained using gears. So, this statement is wrong (3) Bending load is not transferred transverse to shaft axis as there is no transverse load. (4) Rotation is transferred along shaft axis So, this statement is correct

question: Question 74 If [latex]\sigma _{1}[/latex]   and [latex]\sigma _{3}[/latex]    are the algebraically largest and smallest principal stresses respectively, the value of the maximum shear stress is
solution: Maximum shear stress [latex]=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{3}}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 75 A rod of length 20mm is stretched to make a rod of length 40 mm. Subsequently, it is compressed to make a rod of final length 10 mm. Consider the longitudinal tensile strain as positive and compressive strain as negative. The total true longitudinal strain in the rod is_______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \varepsilon_{E} &=\frac{4-L_{0}}{L_{0}}=\frac{10-20}{20}=-0.5 \\ \varepsilon_{T} &=\ln \left[1+\varepsilon_{E}\right]=\ln [1-0.5] \\ &=-0.693 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 76 The principal stresses at a point in a critical section of a machine component are [latex]\sigma _{1}=60[/latex] MPa, [latex]\sigma _{2}=5[/latex] MPa and [latex]\sigma _{2}=-40[/latex] MPa. For the material of the component, the tensile yield strength is [latex]\sigma _{y}=200[/latex] MPa. According to the maximum shear stress theory, the factor of safety is
solution: As per max. shear stress theory, safe condition for design, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Absolute } \tau_{\max }&=\frac{S_{Y S}}{N} \text { or } \frac{S_{Y_{t}}}{2 N}\\ \text{Absolute }\tau_{\max }&= \text{larger of}\\ &\begin{array}{l} {\left[\left|\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}\right|,\left|\frac{\sigma_{2}-\sigma_{3}}{2}\right|,\left|\frac{\sigma_{3}-\sigma_{1}}{2}\right|\right]} \\ =\left|\frac{\sigma_{3}-\sigma_{1}}{2}\right| \end{array}\\ &\left[\because \sigma_{1} \text { and } \sigma_{3} \text { are unlike in nature }\right] \\ &=\left|\frac{-40-60}{2}\right|=50 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text{Hence,}\quad50&=\frac{200}{2(N)}\\ N&=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 77 A steel bar is held by two fixed supports as shown in the figure and is subjected to an increases of temperature [latex]\Delta T=100^{\circ}C[/latex].If the coefficent of thermal exapnasion and young's  modules of elasticity of steel  are [latex]11\, \times \, 10^{-6} \, /^{\circ}C[/latex] and 200GPa, respectively, the magnitude of thermal stress (in MPa) induced in the bar is _____
solution: We know that for completely restricted expansion, thermal stress developed in bar is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{t h} &=\alpha(\Delta T) E \\ &=11 \times 10^{-6} \times 100 \times 200 \times 10^{3}\\ &=220 \mathrm{MPa}\text{(comp. in native)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 78 A cantilever beam of length L and flexural modulus EI is subjected to a point load P at the free end. The elastic strain energy stored in the beam due to bending (neglecting transverse shear) is
solution: Let U is the S.E. in the beam due to B.M.  (M) [latex]U=\int_{0}^{L}\frac{(M_{x-x})^2 dx}{2(EI)_{x-x}}=\int_{0}^{L}\frac{(Px)^2 dx}{2EI_{NA}} [/latex] [latex]U=\frac{P^2}{2EI_{NA}}\int_{0}^{L}x^2dx=\frac{P^2}{2EI}\left ( \frac{L^3}{3} \right ) [/latex] [latex]U=\frac{P^2L^3}{6EI_{NA}}[/latex]

question: Question 79 For a loaded cantilever beam of uniform cross-section, the bending moment (in N.mm) along the length is [latex]M(x)=5x^{2}+10x[/latex] , where x is the distance (in mm) measured from the free end of the beam. The magnitude of shear force (in N) in the cross-section at x=10 mm is
solution: [latex](\mathrm{BM})_{x-x}=M_{x-x}=5 x^{2}+10 x[/latex] [latex] \text { (S.F) }_{x-x}=F_{x-x}=?[/latex] We know that at section X-X [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{X-X} &=\frac{d}{d x}\left[5 x^{2}+10 x\right] \\ F_{X-X} &=10 x+10 \\ \left(F_{X-X}\right)_{x=10 \mathrm{mm}} &=10(10)+10=110 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 The state of stress at a point is [latex]\sigma _{x}=\sigma _{y}=\sigma _{z}=t_{xz}=t_{zx}=t_{yz}=t_{zy}=0[/latex] and [latex]t_{xy}=t_{yx}=50MPa[/latex] . The maximum normal stress (in MPa) at that point is_____.
solution: Given state of stress condition indicates pure shear state of stress. For pure shear state of stress, Max. tensile stress = Max. comp. stress = Max. Shear stress [latex] =\tau_{X Y}=50 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] Hence, Max. normal stress [latex] =50 \mathrm{MPa} [/latex]

question:
Question 81 A horizontal bar, fixed at one end (x = 0), has a length of 1 m, and cross-sectional area of [latex]100\,mm^{2}[/latex].   Its elastic modulus varies along its length as given by [latex]E(x)=100\,e^{-x}\,[/latex]  Where x is the length coordinate 
(in m) along the axis of the bar. An axial tensile load of 10 kN is applied at the free end (x=1). The axial displacement of the free end is _______ mm.
solution: Change in length of small strip, [latex] \delta=\frac{P_{x-x}(d x)}{A_{x-x} E_{x x}}[/latex] Total change in length of bar, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{\text {total }} &=\int_{0}^{L} \delta=\int_{0}^{L} \frac{\left(P_{x-x}\right)(d x)}{\left(A_{x-x}\right) E_{x-x}} \\ P_{x-x} &=P=\text { Constant } \\ A_{x-x} &=A=\text { Constant } \\ E_{x-x} &=100 e^{-x} \text { GPA } \\ \delta_{\text {tolal }} &=\frac{P}{A} \int_{0}^{L} \frac{d x}{100 e^{-x}} \\ &=\frac{P}{10^{9} \times 100 A} \int_{0}^{L} \frac{d x}{e^{-x}} \\ &=\frac{10000}{1000 \times \frac{100 \times 10^{9}}{10^{6}} }\int_{0}^{1}\frac{d x}{e^{-x}} \\ &=\frac{1}{1000}[1.7183] m \\ \text{Hence,}\quad &=1.7183 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 82 A rectangular region in a solid is in a state of plane strain. The (x,y) coordinates of the corners of the under deformed rectangle are given by P(0,0), Q (4,0), S (0,3). The rectangle is subjected to uniform strains,[latex]\varepsilon _{xx}=0.001[/latex] , [latex]\varepsilon _{yy}=0.002[/latex],[latex]\gamma _{xy}=0.003[/latex].The deformed length of the elongated diagonal, up to three decimal places, is _________ units.
solution: [latex]\tan \theta=\frac{4}{3}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta &=53.13^{\circ} \\ 2 \theta &=106.26^{\circ} \\ \cos 2 \theta &=-0.27999 \\ \sin 2 \theta &=0.96 \end{aligned}[/latex] Normal strain on a oblique plane (i.e. RP) inclined at an angle [latex](\theta)[/latex] is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\varepsilon_{n}\right)_{\theta}=& \frac{1}{2}\left[\varepsilon_{x}+\varepsilon_{y}\right]+\frac{1}{2}\left[\varepsilon_{x}-\varepsilon_{y}\right] \cos 2 \theta \\ & +\left(\frac{\gamma x y}{2}\right) \sin 2 \theta \\ =& \frac{1}{2}[0.001+0.002]+\frac{1}{2}[0.001-0.002] \\ &[-0.27999]+\left(\frac{0.003}{2}\right)(0.96) \\ &\left(\varepsilon_{n}\right)_{\theta=53.13^{\circ}}=0.00308 & \\ =& \frac{\text { Change in length of diagonal }}{\text { Original length of diagonal }}=0.00308 \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, change in length of diagonal [latex] =(0.00308) 5=0.0154 \mathrm{mm}[/latex] deformed length of diagonal [latex] =5+0.0154=5.0154 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question: Question 83 A point mass of 100 kg is dropped onto a massless elastic bar (cross-sectional area=[latex]100\,mm^{2}[/latex] , length = 1m, Young's moduls = 100 GPa) from a height H of 10mm as shown (Figure is not to scale). If [latex]g=10\,m/s^{2}[/latex],, the maximum compression of the elastic bar is _______mm.
solution: Given loading is impact loading [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{\text {impact }} &=\delta_{\text {static }} \times \text { Impact factor } \\ \delta_{\text {static }} &=\frac{W L}{A E}=\frac{100 \times 10 \times 1000}{100 \times 100 \times 10^{3}} \\ &=0.1 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Impact factor (I.F.) [latex] =1+\sqrt{1+\frac{2 h}{\delta_{\text {static }}}}[/latex] [latex] =1+\sqrt{1+\frac{2 \times 10}{0.1}}=15.178[/latex] Hence maximum compression of bar = Impact elongation [latex] =0.1 \times 15.178=1.5178 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 84 An initially stress-free massless elastic beam of length L and circular cross-section with diameter d [latex](d \lt \! \lt l)[/latex] is held fixed between two walls as shown. The beam material has Young's modulus E and coefficient of thermal expansion [latex]\alpha[/latex] . If the beam is slowly and uniformly heated, the temperature rise required to cause the beam to buckle is proportional to
solution: Condition for buckling, (Reaction offered by the fixed support)[latex]\gt [/latex] Buckling load [latex] \begin{aligned} i.e. R&>P e\\ \sigma_{\mathrm{Th}} A>& \frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\mathrm{min}}}{L_{e}^{2}} \\ \alpha(\Delta T) E A>& \frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{\left(L_{\theta}\right)^{2}}\\ \text{for cicular cross-section}\\ \alpha(\Delta T) E \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} &>\frac{\pi^{2} E}{\left(L_{e}\right)^{2}} \frac{\pi}{64} d^{4} \\ \Delta T &>\frac{\pi^{2} d^{2}}{16 \alpha\left(L_{\theta}\right)^{2}} \\ \text{Hence,}\quad \Delta T & \propto d^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 In the engineering stress-strain curve for mild steel, the Ultimate Tensile Strength (UTS) refers to
solution: Ultimate tensile strength represents the max. stress that a material can withstand without fracture.

question: Question 86 In a metal forming operation when the material has just started yielding, the principal stresses are [latex]\sigma _{1}=+180[/latex]  Mpa,[latex]\sigma _{2}=-100[/latex] Mpa,[latex]\sigma _{3}=0[/latex]. Following Von Mises criterion, the yield stress is ________ MPa.
solution: Safe condition for design as per von-Mises criterion, [latex] \sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2}-\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2} \leq\left(\frac{S_{y t}}{N}\right)^{2}[/latex] When yielding occurs, N=1 [latex] \begin{array}{r} \sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2}-\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2}=\left(S_{y t}\right)^{2} \\ (180)^{2}+(-100)^{2}-(180)(-100)=\left(S_{y t}\right)^{2} \\ S_{t y}=245.7641 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 87 Consider a beam with circular cross-section of diameter d. The ratio of the second moment of area about the neutral axis to the section modulus of the area is.
solution: [latex]\frac{I_{N . A}}{Z_{N . A}}=\frac{I_{N, A_{.}}}{\left(I_{N . A} / Y_{\max }\right)}=Y_{\max }[/latex] For a solid circular cross-section [latex] Y_{\max }=d / 2[/latex]

question: Question 88 A motor is driving a solid circular steel shaft transmits 40kW of power at 500 rpm. If the diameter of the shaft is 40 mm, The maximum shear stress in the shaft is ____MPa.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T &=\frac{P \times 60 \times 10^{6}}{2 \pi N}=\frac{40 \times 60 \times 10^{6}}{2 \pi(500)} \\ &=763943.7268 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm} \\ \tau_{\max } &=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}}=\frac{16 \times 763943.7268}{\pi(40)^{3}} \\ &=60.792 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 The poisson's ratio for a perfectly incompressible linear material is
solution: For perfectly incompressible material, poisson's ratio =0.5 (if change in vol. should be zero,[latex] \mu=0.5[/latex])

question: Question 90 A beam of length L is carrying a uniformly distributed load w per unit length. The flexural rigidity of the beam is EI. The reaction at the simple support at the right end is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta_{B} &=0 \\ \frac{W L^{4}}{8 E I}-\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I} &=0 \\ \therefore\quad R&=\frac{3 W L}{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 91 Two circular shafts made of same material, one solid (S) and one hollow (H), have the same length and polar moment of inertia. Both are subjected to same torque. Here,  [latex]\theta_{s}[/latex] is the twist and [latex]\tau_{s}[/latex] is the maximum shear stress in the solid shaft, whereas [latex]\theta_{H}[/latex] is the twist and [latex]\tau_{H}[/latex] is the maximum shear stress in the hollow shaft. Which one of the following is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_s=L_H, & T_s=T_H=T,\\ I_{ps} &=I_{pH}\\ \therefore \; \frac{\pi}{32}d^4&=\frac{\pi}{32}(d_o^4-d_i^4)\\ \therefore \; d_o & \gt d\\ \therefore \;r_o &\ gt r\\ \text{Angle of twist}\\ \theta &=\frac{TL}{GI_p}\\ \therefore \; \theta _s&=\theta _H\\ \tau _{max_s}&=\frac{I}{I_p}r\\ \tau _{max_H}&=\frac{I}{I_p}r_o\\ \therefore \; \tau _{max_H}& \gt \tau _{max_s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 92 A square plate of dimension  L x L is subjected to a uniform pressure load p = 250 MPa on its edges as shown in the figure. Assume plane stress conditions. The Young's modulus E = 200 GPa. The deformed shape is a square of dimension [latex]L-2\delta[/latex] . If L= 2 m  and  [latex]\delta[/latex]=0.001 m, the Poisson's ratio of the plate material is __________
solution: Strain in horizontal direction [latex] \begin{array}{l} \frac{-2 \delta}{L}=\frac{-P}{E}+\mu \frac{P}{E} \\ \frac{-2 \delta}{L} E=P(-1+\mu) \Rightarrow \frac{-2 \delta E}{L P}=1-\mu \\ \therefore \quad \mu=1-\frac{-2 \delta E}{L P} \\ =1-\frac{2 \times 0.001 \times 200 \times 10^{3}}{2 \times 250}=1-0.8=0.2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 93 The state of stress at a point on an element is shown in figure (a). The same state of stress is shown in another coordinate system in figure (b). The components ([latex]\tau _{xx},\tau _{yy},\tau _{xy}[/latex])  are given by
solution: The given plane is principal plane [latex] \left(\sigma_{1}=P, \sigma_{2}=-P\right) [/latex]. At [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex] from principal plane, plane of max shear occurs. On the plane of max shear. [latex] \begin{aligned} \operatorname{both}, \quad \tau_{x y} &=\tau_{y y}=\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{2}=0 \\ \tau_{x y} &=\frac{\sigma_{1}+\sigma_{2}}{2}=P \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 94 The cross-sections of two solid bars made of the same material are shown in the figure. The square cross-section has flexural (bending) rigidity I1, while the circular cross-section has flexural rigidity I2. Both sections have the same cross-sectional area. The ratio I1/I2 is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad b^{2}&=\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{b^{2}}{d^{2}}&=\frac{\pi}{4} \\ I_{1} &=\frac{b^{4}}{12} \\ I_{2} &=\frac{\pi d^{4}}{64} \\ \therefore \qquad \frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}} &=\frac{b^{4}}{12} \times \frac{64}{\pi d^{4}}=\frac{16}{3 \pi} \frac{b^{4}}{d^{4}} \\ &=\frac{16}{3 \pi} \cdot \frac{\pi^{2}}{16}=\frac{\pi}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 95 A circular metallic rod of length 250 mm is placed between two rigid immovable walls as shown in the figure. The rod is in perfect contact with the wall on the left side and there is a gap of 0.2 mm between the rod and the wall on the right side. If the temperature of the rod is increased by  [latex]200^{\circ}C[/latex] , the axial stress developed in the rod is __________ MPa Young's modulus of the material of the rod is 200 GPa and the coefficient of thermal expansion is  [latex]10^{-5}per^{\circ}C[/latex]
solution: Free expansion of rod[latex]=L \alpha \Delta T [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=250 \times 10^{-5} \times 200\\&=0.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \text { Actual expansion } &=0.2 \mathrm{mm}\\ \therefore \quad \text{Expansion resisted} &=0.3 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \quad \text{Strain resisted } &=\frac{0.3}{250} \\ \text { Stress developed } &=\frac{0.3}{250} \times 200 \times 10^{3} \\ &=0.24 \times 10^{3}=240 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 A simply supported beam of length 2L is subjected to a moment M at the mid-point x = 0 as shown in the figure. The deflection in the domain [latex]o\leq x\leq L[/latex] is given by [latex]w=\frac{-Mx}{12EIL}(L-x)(x+c)[/latex] where E is the Young's modulus, I is the area moment of inertia and c is a constant (to be determined) The slope at the center x = 0 is
solution: Equation of deflection [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=\frac{-M}{12 E I L}\left[L x^{2}-x^{3}+L c x-C x^{2}\right] \\ \frac{d W}{d x} &=\frac{-M}{12 E I L}\left[2 L x-3 x^{2}+L C-2 C x\right] \\ \frac{d^{2} W}{d x^{2}} &=\frac{-M}{12 E I L}[2 L-6 x-2 C] \\ \therefore \quad E I \frac{d^{2} W}{d x^{2}} &=\frac{-M}{12 L}[2 L-6 x-2 C] \\ \text { now } \quad E I \frac{d^{2} W}{d x^{2}} &=\frac{-M}{12 L}[2 L-6 x-2 C]\\ \text{at }\quad x&=L, M_{x}=0 \\ \therefore \quad C&=2 L\\ Slope\\ \frac{d W}{d x} &=\frac{-M}{12 E I L}\left[2 L x-3 x^{2}+2 L^{2}-4 L x\right] \\ \therefore \quad \left|\frac{d W}{d x}\right|_{x=0} &=\frac{-M L}{6 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 A rigid horizontal rod of length 2L is fixed to a circular cylinder of radius R as shown in the figure. Vertical forces of magnitude P are applied at the two ends as shown in the figure. The shear modulus for the cylinder is G and the Young's modulus is E. The vertical deflection at point A is
solution: Angle of twist [latex]\theta [/latex] [latex]\theta =\frac{(2PL)L}{GI_p}=\frac{2PL^2}{G\frac{\pi}{2}R^4}=\frac{4PL^2}{\pi GR^4}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \;[/latex] Vertical deflection of A [latex]\Delta _A=\theta L=\frac{4PL^3}{\pi G R^4}[/latex]

question: Question 98 A machine element XY, fixed at end X, is subjected to an axial load P, transverse load F, and a twisting moment T at its free end Y. The most critical point from the strength point of view is

options.A: a point on the circumference at location Y
options.B: a point at the center at location Y
options.C: a point on the circumference at location X
options.D: a point at the center at location X

solution: Both bending stress and shear stress (due to  torque) will be max at the circumference. The bending stress will be maximum at x. Hence, critical section will be at a point on the  circumference at location x.

question: Question 99 A thin cylindrical pressure vessel with closed-ends is subjected to internal pressure. The ratio of circumferential (hoop) stress to the longitudinal stress is
solution: For thin cylinder Circumferential stress [latex] \sigma_{h}=\frac{p d}{2 t}[/latex] Longitudinal stress, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{L} &=\frac{p d}{4 t} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\sigma_{h} }{\sigma_{L}} &=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 100 A shaft with a circular cross-section is subjected to pure twisting moment. The ratio of the maximum shear stress to the largest principal stress is
solution: For the case of pure shear [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{1} &=\tau_{\max } \\ \sigma_{2} &=-\tau_{\max } \\ \text { Required ratio } &=\tau_{\max } / \sigma_{1}=\sigma_{1} / \sigma_{1}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 101 A hypothetical engineering stress-strain curve shown in the figure has three straight lines PQ, QR, RS with coordinates P(0,0), Q(0.2,100), R(0.6,140) and S(0.8,130). 'Q' is the yield point, 'R' is the UTS point and 'S' the fracture point. The toughness of the material (in MJ/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] ) is __________
solution: Toughness is area of curve upto S on strain axis [latex] \begin{array}{l} \left[\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{0.2}{100} \times 100\right]+\left\{\frac{[100+140]}{2} \times \frac{0.4}{100}\right\}\\+\left\{\frac{140+130}{2}\right\}\times\frac{0.2}{100}\\ =0.1+0.48+0.27=0.85 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 102 The principal stresses at a point inside a solid object are [latex]\sigma _{1}=100[/latex]  Mpa, [latex]\sigma _{2}=100[/latex] MPa and [latex]\sigma _{3}=0[/latex] Mpa.  The yield strength of the material is 200 MPa. The factor of safety calculated using Tresca (maximum shear stress) theory is [latex]n_{T}[/latex] and the factor of safety calculated using von Mises (maximum distortional energy) theory is [latex]n_{V}[/latex]. Which one of the following relations is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \sigma_{1}=100 \mathrm{MPa}, \sigma_{2}=100 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma_{3}=0 \\ \sigma_{y}=200 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex] According to Tresca theory [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{\max } & \leq \frac{\sigma_{y}}{2 F O S} \\ \tau_{\max } &=\frac{\sigma_{y}}{2 n_{T}} \\ \text{now}\quad \tau_{\max _{\mathrm{abs}}} &=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{3}}{2}=50 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \therefore \quad 50 &=\frac{200}{2 n_{T}}\\ \therefore \quad n_{T}&=2 \end{aligned}[/latex] According to Von-Mises theory [latex] \begin{array}{l} \sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2}-\sigma_{1} \sigma_{2} \leq\left(\frac{\sigma_{y}}{n_{V}}\right)^{2} \\ 100^{2}+100^{2}-100 \times 100 \leq\left(\frac{200}{n_{V}}\right)^{2} \\ \therefore \quad 100=\frac{200}{n_{v}}\\ \text{or}\quad n_{v}=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 103 A simply-supported beam of length 3L is subjected to the loading shown in the figure. It is given that P = 1 N, L = 1 m and Young's modulus E = 200 GPa. The cross-section is a square with dimension 10 mm x 10 mm. The bending stress (in Pa) at the point A located at the top surface of the beam at a distance of 1.5L from the left end is _____________ (Indicate compressive stress by a negative sign and tensile stress by a positive sign.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{V} &=0 \\ R_{1}+R_{2} &=0 \\ \Sigma M_{1} &=0 \\ 3 R_{2} L-2 P L+P L &=0 \\ R_{2} &=\frac{P}{3} \\ R_{1} &=\frac{-P}{3}\\ \mathrm{B.M} \text { at } A,\; M_{A}&=\left(R_{1} \times 1.5 L\right)+(P \times 0.5 L) \\ &=\left(\frac{-P}{3} \times 1.5 L\right)+0.5 P L=0\\ \therefore \text{B.M. at A} &= 0\\ \therefore \text{Bending stress }&= 0\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 104 The figure shows cross-section of a beam subjected to bending. The area moment of inertia (in [latex]mm^{4}[/latex] ) of this cross-section about its base is __________
solution: Area moment of Inertia of rectangular cross-section about its centre of gravity [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{C . G} &=\frac{b d^{3}}{12}=\frac{10 \times 20^{3}}{12} \\ &=6666.67 \mathrm{mm}^{4} \end{aligned}[/latex] Area moment of inertia of rectangular crosssection about its base [latex] \begin{array}{l} =I_{C . G}+A y^{2} \\ =6666.67+(10 \times 20) \times(10)^{2} \\ =26,666.67 \mathrm{mm}^{4} \end{array}[/latex] Area moment of inertia of two semi-circle of equal radii about its centre of gravity [latex] \begin{array}{l} =2 \times\left[\frac{1}{2} \frac{\pi}{64} d^{4}\right] \\ =2 \times\left[\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{\pi}{64} \times\left\{8^{4}\right\}\right] \\ =201.0619 \mathrm{mm}^{4} \end{array}[/latex] Area moment of inertia of two semi-circle of equal radii about base [latex] \begin{array}{l} =I_{C G}+A y^{2} \\ =201.0619+\left[2 \times \frac{1}{2} \pi \times 4^{2}\right][10]^{2} \\ =5227.61 \mathrm{mm}^{4} \end{array}[/latex] Area moment of inertia of configuration given in question about its base [latex] \begin{array}{l} =26, 666.67-5227.61\\ =21439.06\mathrm{mm}^{4} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 105 A horizontal bar with a constant cross-section is subjected to loading as shown in the figure. The Young's moduli for the sections AB and BC are 3E and E, respectively For the deflection at C to be zero, the ratio P/F is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta_{C} &=0 \\ \Delta_{B C}+\Delta_{A B} &=0 \\ \frac{F L}{A E}+\frac{(F-P) L}{A \times 3 E} &=0 \\ F+\frac{F-P}{3} &=0 \\ 3 F+F-P &=0 \\ 4 F &=P \\ \frac{P}{F} &=4 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 106 A cantilever beam having square cross-section of side a is subjected to an end load. If a is increased by 19%, the tip deflection decreases approximately by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta_{B} &=\frac{P L^{3}}{3 E I} \\ \therefore \quad \Delta & \propto \frac{1}{I}\\ \text{For square c-s} \\ I &=\frac{a^{4}}{12} \\ \frac{\Delta_{1}}{\Delta_{2}} &=\frac{I_{2}}{I_{1}}=2.005 \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\Delta_{1}}{\Delta_{2}} &=\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{(1.19 a)^{4}}{a^{4}} \\ \therefore \quad \Delta_{2} &=\frac{\Delta_{1}}{2.005}=0.5 \Delta_{1} \end{aligned}[/latex]
