question: Question 107 The cross sections of two hollow bars made of the same material are concentric circles as shown in the figure. It is given that [latex]r_{3}>r_{1}[/latex]  and [latex]r_{4}>r_{2}[/latex] and that the areas of the cross-sections are the same.J1 and J2 are the torsional rigidities of the bars on the left and right, respectively. The ratio J2/J1 is
solution: C.S. area of both is same [latex] r_{2}^{2}-r_{1}^{2}=r_{4}^{2}-r_{3}^{2}[/latex] Torsional rigidity [latex] \begin{array}{l} J_{1}=G I_{p 1}=G \frac{\pi}{2}\left(r_{2}^{4}-r_{1}^{4}\right) \\ J_{2}=G I_{p 2}=G \frac{\pi}{2}\left(r_{4}^{4}-r_{3}^{4}\right) \\ \therefore \qquad \frac{J_{2}}{J_{1}}=\frac{r_{4}^{4}-r_{3}^{4}}{r_{2}^{4}-r_{1}^{4}}=\frac{\left(r_{4}^{2}-r_{3}^{2}\right)\left(r_{4}^{2}+r_{3}^{2}\right)}{\left(r_{2}^{2}-r_{1}^{2}\right)\left(r_{2}^{2}+r_{1}^{2}\right)} \\ \therefore \qquad \frac{J_{2}}{J_{1}}=\frac{r_{4}^{2}+r_{3}^{2}}{r_{2}^{2}+r_{1}^{2}}\\ \therefore \qquad r_{4}>r_{2}, r_{3}>r_{1}\\ \therefore \qquad \frac{J_{2}}{J_{1}} \gt 1 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 108 For the overhanging beam shown in figure, the magnitude of maximum bending moment (in kN-m) is ________
solution: [latex]\therefore \quad R_{A}+R_{B}=60 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Taking moment from point B [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{A} \times 4+20+2 &=40 \times 2 \\ 4 R_{A} &=10 \mathrm{kN} \\ R_{B} &=50 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking x from A [latex] \begin{aligned} M x &=R_{A} \times x-W \frac{x^{2}}{2} \\ &=10 x-5 x^{2}\\ \text{at}\;x&=1,M_{1}=5 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \text{at}\; B, M_{B}&=-40\\ |M|&=40 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 109 The value of moment of inertia of the section shown in the figure about the axis-XX is

Question 110 A cylindrical tank with closed ends is filled with compressed air at a pressure of 500 kPa. The inner radius of the tank is 2 m, and it has wall thickness of 10 mm. The magnitude of maximum in-plane shear stress (in MPa) is ________
solution: Maximum in plane shear stress (in MPa) [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}=\frac{\frac{p d}{2 t}-\frac{p d}{4 t}}{2} \\ &=\frac{500 \times 10^{3} \times 4000}{8 \times 10}=25 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{Pa}=25 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 111 A hollow shaft ([latex]d_{o}[/latex] = 2[latex]d_{i}[/latex]  where [latex]d_{o}[/latex] and [latex]d_{i}[/latex] are the outer and inner diameters respectively) needs to transmit 20 kW power at 3000 RPM. If the maximum permissible shear stress is 30 MPa, [latex]d_{o}[/latex]  is
solution: Given data, [latex]\begin{aligned} d_{o} &=2 d_{i} \\ k &=\frac{d_{i}}{d_{o}}=0.5 \\ P &=20 \mathrm{kW} \\ N &=3000 \mathrm{RPM} \\ \frac{2 \pi \mathrm{NT}}{60} &=P \\ \text{or}\quad T &=\frac{60 \times 20 \times 10^{3}}{2 \pi \times 3000}\\ \Rightarrow & 63.66197 \mathrm{Nm} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \tau_{\max } &=\frac{16 T}{\pi d_{0}^{3}\left(1-k^{4}\right)} \\ 30 &=\frac{16 \times 63.66197 \times 10^{3}}{\pi \times d_{0}^{3}\left(1-0.5^{4}\right)} \\ \text { or } \quad d_{0} &=22.59 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 112 A hollow shaft of 1 m length is designed to transmit a power of 30 kW at 700 rpm. The maximum permissible angle of twist in the shaft is [latex]1^{\circ}[/latex]. The inner diameter of the shaft is 0.7 times the outer diameter. The modulus of rigidity is 80 GPa. The outside diameter (in mm) of the shaft is__________
solution: Given data, [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=30 \mathrm{kW} \\ N &=700 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \frac{2 \pi \mathrm{NT}}{60} &=30 \times 10^{3}=P\\ \text { or } \quad T&=409.25 \mathrm{Nm} \\ \theta=& \frac{T L}{G J} \\ \therefore \frac{1 \times \pi}{180}&=\frac{409.25 \times 10^{3} \times 10^{3} \times 32}{\pi \times\left(d_{0}\right)^{4}\left(1-0.7^{4}\right) \times 80 \times 10^{3}} \\ \text { or } \quad d_{0}&= 44.5212  \mathrm{mm}  \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 113 In a plane stress condition, the components of stress at a point are [latex]\sigma_{x}=20 MPa[/latex] ,[latex]\sigma_{y}=80 MPa[/latex] and [latex]\tau _{xy}=40 MPa[/latex] . The maximum shear stress (in MPa) at the point is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \sigma_{1,2}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}\right)^{2}+4 \tau_{x y}^{2}}\right] \\ =\frac{1}{2}[100 \pm \sqrt{(60)^{2}+4 \times 40^{2}}] \\ \sigma_{1}=100 \\ \sigma_{2}=0 \\ \tau_{\max }=\sigma_{1} / 2=50 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 114 A cantilever beam with square cross-section of 6 mm side is subjected to a load of 2 kN normal to the top surface as shown in the figure. The Young's modulus of elasticity of the material of the beam is 210 GPa. The magnitude of slope (in radian) at Q (20 mm from the fixed end) is ________
solution: Slope [latex]\theta_{Q}-\theta_{0}=\frac{1}{E I}[\text { Area of diagram till } Q] [/latex] Area of diagram till " Q " [latex] \left[\frac{1}{2} \times 100 \times 2 \times 10^{5}\right]-\left[\frac{1}{2} \times 80 \times y\right][/latex] Calculating; y from properties of similar triangles. [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{y}{2 \times 10^{5}} &=\frac{80}{100} \\ y &=160,000 \mathrm{Nmm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Area of diagram till Q [latex] \begin{array}{l} \Rightarrow\left[1 / 2 \times 100 \times 2 \times 10^{5}\right]-[1 / 2 \times 80 \times 160,000] \\ =3600000 \mathrm{N} . \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ \theta_{Q}=\frac{1}{210 \times 10^{3} \times I} \times 3600000 \\ I=\frac{b d^{3}}{12}=\frac{b^{4}}{12}=\frac{b^{4}}{12}=108 \mathrm{mm}^{4} \\ \theta_{Q}=\frac{1}{210 \times 10^{3} \times 108} \times 3600000 \\ =0.1587 \mathrm{rad} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 115 A cantilever beam OP is connected to another beam PQ with a pin joint as shown in the figure. A load of 10 kN is applied at the mid-point of PQ. The magnitude of bending moment (in kN-m) at fixed end O is
solution: At hinge moment releases Taking summation of all forces [latex] P_{V}+R_{Q}=10[/latex] Taking moment of all forces about Q [latex] M=\underset{clockwise}{\left(P_{V} \times 1\right)}-\underset{anticlockwise}{(10 \times 0.5)}[/latex] At equilibrium M=0 [latex] \begin{array}{rl} \therefore \quad 0 & =\left(P_{V} \times 1\right)-5 \\ P_{V} & =5 \mathrm{kN} \end{array}[/latex] Summation of all vertical forces is zero. [latex] \therefore \quad O_{V}+P_{V}=0 [/latex] Summation of Moments of all forces at equilibrium is zero. [latex] \therefore \quad\underset{clockwise}{+M}+\underset{clockwise}{P_{v}\times 2}=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore M=-P_{V} \times 2[/latex] [latex] \text{where}\quad P_{V}=-5 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [latex] \therefore M=10 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question: Question 116 A gas is stored in a cylindrical tank of inner radius 7 m and wall thickness 50 mm. The gage pressure of the gas is 2 MPa. The maximum shear stress (in MPa) in the wall is
solution: Maximum shear stress in the wall [latex] =\frac{\sigma_{1}}{2}=\frac{p d}{4 t}=\frac{2 \times 14 \times 1000}{4 \times 50}=140 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 117 A rod is subjected to a uni-axial load within linear elastic limit. When the change in the stress is   200 MPa, the change in the strain is 0.001. If the Poisson's ratio of the rod is 0.3, the modulus of rigidity (in GPa) is ________________
solution: With in linear elastic limit [latex] \sigma=E \in[/latex] [latex] E \rightarrow \text{ slope of } \sigma \text{ vs }\in \text{ curve}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} E &=\frac{d \sigma}{d \epsilon}=\frac{200}{0.001}=200 \mathrm{GPa} \\ E &=2 G[1+\mu] \\ G &=\frac{E}{2(1+\mu)}=\frac{200}{2(1+0.3)}=\frac{100}{1.3} \\ &=76.9230 \mathrm{GPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 118 A cantilever beam with flexural rigidity of 200 N.[latex]m^{2}[/latex]  is loaded as shown in the figure. The deflection (in mm) at the tip of the beam is  _______
solution: [latex]EI=200\mathrm{Nm}^{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} y_{c} &=y_{B}+\theta_{B}(1-a) \\ y_{B} &=\frac{P a^{3}}{3 E I} \\ &=\frac{500 \times\left\{\frac{50}{1000}\right\}^{3}}{3 \times 200} \\ &=1.04167 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m} \\ \theta_{B} &=\frac{P a^{2}}{2 E I} \\ &=\frac{500 \times\left\{\frac{50}{1000}\right\}^{2}}{2 \times 200} \\ &=3.125 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{rad} \\ y_{c}=& y_{B}+\theta_{B}(L-a) \\ &=\left[1.04167 \times 10^{-4}\right] \\ &\qquad+\left[3.125 \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{50}{1000}\right] \\ &=2.60417 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m} \\ &=0.26042 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 119 Which one of the following types of stress-strain relationship best describes the behaviour of brittle materials, such as ceramics and thermosetting plastics, ([latex]\sigma[/latex] = stress and [latex]\varepsilon[/latex] = strain)?
solution: We know that brittle material does not show elongation when external load is applied on them and alter certain amount of load they get cracked from unexpected point. The amount of ultimate load and point of fracture can not be predetermined and elongation is also very-very less so these properties are best described by option (D).

question: Question 120 Consider a steel (Young's modulus E = 200 GPa) column hinged on both sides. Its height is 1.0 m and cross-section is 10 mm x 20 mm. The lowest Euler critical buckling load (in N) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F &=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{L_{e}^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2} \times 200 \times 10^{3} \times 20 \times 10^{3}}{12 \times(1000)^{3}} \\ &=3289.868 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 121 Consider a stepped shaft subjected to a twisting moment applied at B as shown in the figure. Assume shear modulus, G = 77 GPa. The angle of twist at C (in degrees) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta_{C}=\theta_{B} &=\frac{T L}{G J} \\ &=\frac{10 \times 10^{3} \times 500 \times 32}{\pi \times(20)^{4} \times 77 \times 10^{3}} \\ &=4.1338946 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{radian}=0.2368^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 122 A frame is subjected to a load P as shown in the figure. The frame has a constant flexural rigidity EI. The effect of axial load is neglected. The deflection at point A due to the applied load P is
solution: Bending moment in section AB [latex] \begin{aligned} M &=-P x \\ \frac{\partial M}{\partial P} &=-x \end{aligned}[/latex] Bending moment in section BC: [latex] \begin{aligned} M&=-P L\\ \frac{\partial M}{\partial P}&=-L \\ \delta_{A}&=\frac{1}{E I}\left[\int_{0}^{L}(-P x)(-x) d x+\int_{0}^{L}(-P L)(-L) d x\right] \\ \delta_{A}&=\frac{P}{E I}\left[\int_{0}^{L} x^{2} d x+L^{2} \int_{0}^{L} d x\right] \\ &=\frac{P}{E I}\left(\frac{L^{3}}{3}+L^{3}\right)=\frac{4 P L^{3}}{3 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 123 A thin gas cylinder with an internal radius of 100 mm is subject to an internal pressure of 10 MPa. The maximum permissible working stress is restricted to 100 MPa. The minimum cylinder wall thickness (in mm) for safe design must be  _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{\text {wothing }} &=\frac{p d}{2 t} \quad(d=2 r=200 \mathrm{mm}) \\ t &=\frac{p d}{2 \sigma_{w}}=\frac{10 \times 200}{2 \times 100}=10 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 124 The number of independent elastic constants required to define the stress-strain relationship for an isotropic elastic solid is  _______
solution: (1.9 to 2.1) Either E or  G, 2  independent constant Either G or K, 2  independent constant Either E or K, 2  independent constant

question: Question 125 If the Poisson's ratio of an elastic material is 0.4, the ratio of modulus of rigidity to Young's modulus is  _______
solution: [latex](0.35 \text { to } 0.36) [/latex] [latex] E=2 G(1+v) [/latex] [latex] \frac{G}{E}=\frac{1}{2(1+v)}=\frac{1}{2 \times 1.4}=\frac{1}{2.8}=0.357[/latex]

question: Question 126 A force P is applied at a distance x from the end of the beam as shown in the figure. What would be the value of x so that the displacement at 'A' is equal to zero?
solution: Deflection due to load [latex]=\frac{P L^{3}}{3 E I}(-v e) [/latex] Deflection due to moment [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{M L^{2}}{2 E I}=\frac{P(L-x) L^{2}}{2 E I}(+v e) \\ \delta_{P}+\delta_{M} &=0 \\ \therefore \frac{P(L-x) L^{2}}{2 E I} &=\frac{P L^{3}}{3 E I}\\ \text{or}\quad \frac{L-x}{2}&=\frac{L}{3} \\ \text{or}\quad 3 L-3 x &= 2 L \\ \text{or}\quad x &= \frac{L}{3}=0.33 L \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 Consider a simply supported beam of length, 50h, with a rectangular cross-section of depth, h, and width, 2h. The beam carries a vertical point load, P, at its mid-point. The ratio of the maximum shear stress to the maximum bending stress in the beam is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau_{\max }=\frac{3}{2} \frac{P_{\max }}{A} &=\frac{3 P_{\max }}{4 h^{2}}=0.75 \frac{P_{\max }}{h^{2}} \\ \tau_{\max }=\frac{0.75}{h^{2}} \frac{P}{2} &=\frac{0.375 P}{h^{2}}\left[\because P_{\max }=\frac{P}{2}\right] \\ M_{\max } &=\frac{P L}{4}=\frac{P \times 50 h}{4}=12.5 \mathrm{Ph} \\ Z &=\frac{b h^{2}}{6}=\frac{h^{3}}{3} \\ \sigma_{\max } &=\frac{M_{\max }}{Z}=\frac{12.5 \mathrm{Ph} \times 3}{h^{3}}=37.5 \frac{P}{h^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad \frac{\tau_{\max }}{\sigma_{\max }} &=\frac{0.375}{37.5}=0.01 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 128 The stress-strain curve for mild steel is shown in the figure given below. Choose the correct option referring to both figure and table.
solution: P: Proportional limit Q:  Elastic limit R: UYP S: L Y P T: UTS U: Failure/Rupture

question: Question 129 Two solid circular shafts of radii  [latex]R_{1}[/latex]  and [latex]R_{2}[/latex]  are subjected to same torque. The maximum shear stresses developed in the two shafts are [latex]\tau_{1}[/latex] and [latex]\tau_{2}[/latex] . If [latex]R_{1}[/latex] /[latex]R_{2}[/latex]=2, then [latex]\tau_{2} /\tau_{1}[/latex]  is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau _{max}&=\frac{2T}{\pi R^3}\\ \frac{\tau _2}{\tau _1}&=\left ( \frac{R_1}{R_2} \right )^3\\ &=2^3=8 \;\;(\because \; T_1=T_2=T) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 130 A cantilever beam of length, L, with uniform cross-section and flexural rigidity, EI, is loaded uniformly by a vertical load, w per unit length. The maximum vertical deflection of the beam is given by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} y &=\frac{w x^{2}}{24 E I}\left(x^{2}+6 L^{2}-4 L x\right) \\ \text { and } \delta_{\max } &=\frac{w L^{4}}{8 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 131 The flexural rigidity (EI) of a cantilever beam is assumed to be constant over the length of the beam shown in figure. If a load P and bending moment PL/2 are applied at the free end of the beam then the value of the slope at the free end is
solution: [latex] \theta_{1}=\frac{P L^{2}}{2 E I}[/latex] [latex] \theta_{2}=\frac{M L}{E I}=\frac{P L^{2}}{2 E I}[/latex] By superposition, [latex] \theta=\theta_{1}+\theta_{2}=\frac{P L^{2}}{E I }[/latex]

question: Question 132 A thin plate of uniform thickness is subject to pressure as shown in the figure below Under the assumption of plane stress, which one of the following is correct?

options.A: Normal stress is zero in the z-direction
options.B: Normal stress is tensile in the z-direction
options.C: Normal stress is compressive in the z-direction
options.D: Normal stress varies in the z-direction

solution: Thin plate of uniform thickness pertains to plane stress condition. So, stress out of plane would be zero.

question: Question 133 A steel cube, with all faces free to deform, has Young's modulus, E, Poisson's ratio, v, and coefficient of thermal expansion, [latex]\alpha[/latex]. The pressure (hydrostatic stress) developed within the cube, when it is subjected to a uniform increase in temperature, [latex]\Delta T[/latex], is given by
solution:
As all forces are free to deform, there is no thermal
stress.

question: Question 134 A 200 mm long, stress free rod at room temperature is held between two immovable rigid walls. The temperature of the rod is uniformly raised by 250[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]C. If the Young's modulus and coefficient of thermal expansion are 200 GPa and [latex]1 \times 10^{-5}/C^{\circ}[/latex] , respectively, the magnitude of the longitudinal stress (in MPa) developed in the rod is _______
solution: Given, [latex] \begin{array}{c} l=200 \mathrm{mm} ; \quad \Delta T=250^{\circ} \mathrm{C} ; \quad \alpha=1 \times 10^{-5} /^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ E=200 \mathrm{GPa} ; \quad \sigma=? \\ \sigma=\alpha \Delta T E=10^{-5} \times 250 \times 200 \times 10^{3} \\ =500 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 135 Consider a cantilever beam, having negligible mass and uniform flexural rigidity, with length  0.01 m. The frequency of vibration of the beam, with a 0.5 kg mass attached at the free tip, is  100 Hz. The flexural rigidity (in N.[latex]m^{2}[/latex] ) of the beam is _______
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} P &=m g=0.5 \times 9.81=4.905 N \\ L &=0.01 \mathrm{m} \\ f_{n} &=100 \mathrm{Hz} \\ \omega_{n} &=2 \pi f_{n}=628 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}\\ \text { or } \quad k&=m \omega_{n}^{2}=0.5 \times(628)^{2}\\ &=197192 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}\\ \delta &=\frac{P L^{3}}{3 E I} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{P}{\delta} &=\frac{3 E I}{L^{3}} \\ \text{or}\quad EI&=\frac{P}{\delta }\times\frac{L^{3}}{3}\\ &=197192 \times \frac{(0.01)^{3}}{3} \\ &=0.06573 \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 136 The state of stress at a point is given by  [latex]\sigma_{x}[/latex]= -6Mpa, [latex]\sigma_{y}[/latex]=4 MPa  and [latex]\tau_{xy}[/latex]=-8 MPa . The maximum tensile stress (in MPa) at the point is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma_{1} &=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ &=\frac{+6-4}{2}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{+6-4}{2}\right)^{2}+(-8)^{2}} \\ &=-1+\sqrt{25+64} \\ &=-1+\sqrt{89}=8.4339 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 137 A mentalic rod of 500 mm length and 50mm diameter, when subjected to a tensile force of 100KN at the ends, experiences an increase in its length by 0.5 mm and a reduction in its diameter by 0.015 m. the poission's ratio of the rod material is_________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} v=-\frac{\text { Lateral strain }}{\text { Longitudinal strain }}=-\frac{\left(\frac{\Delta D}{D}\right)}{\left(\frac{\Delta L}{L}\right)} \\ v=\left(\frac{L}{D}\right)\left(-\frac{\Delta D}{\Delta L}\right) \\ \text{given,}L=500\mathrm{mm},D=50\mathrm{mm}\\ \Delta D=-0.015, \Delta L=+0.5 \mathrm{mm} \\ \qquad v=\frac{500}{50} \times \frac{0.015}{0.500}=0.3 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 138 A circular rod of length 'L' and area of cross-section 'A' has a modulus of elasticity 'E' and coefficient of thermal expansion '[latex]\alpha[/latex]'. One end of the rod is fixed and other end is free. If the temperature of the rod is increased by [latex]\Delta T[/latex], then

options.A: stress developed in the rod is [latex]E\alpha \Delta T[/latex] and strain developed in the rod is [latex]\alpha \Delta T[/latex]
options.B: both stress and strain developed in the rod are zero
options.C: stress developed in the rod is zero and strain developed in the rod is [latex]\alpha \Delta T[/latex]
options.D: stress developed in the rod is [latex]E\alpha \Delta T[/latex] and strain developed in the rod is zero

solution: For thermal stress to be developed, there must be constraint in the system. So, although strain develops but there is no thermal stress.

question:
Question 139 A simply supported beam of length L is subjected to a varying distributed load  [latex]sin(3\pi x/L)Nm^{-1}[/latex]
, where the distance x is measured from the left support. The magnitude of the vertical reaction force in N at the left support is
solution:
Load [latex]
W=\int_{0}^{L} \sin \left(\frac{3 \pi x}{L}\right) d x=\frac{2 L}{3 \pi}[/latex] Vertical reaction, [latex]
R_{1}=R_{2}=\frac{L}{3 \pi}[/latex] (due to symmetrical loading)

question: Question 140 A long thin walled cylindrical shell, closed at both the ends, is subjected to an internal pressure. The ratio of the hoop stress (circumferential  stress) to longitudinal stress developed in the shell is
solution: Hoop stress: [latex]\sigma_{h}=\frac{p d}{2 t}[/latex] Longitudinal stress: [latex]\sigma_{L}=\frac{p d}{4 t} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \frac{\sigma_{h}}{\sigma_{L}}=2[/latex]

question: Question 141 Two threaded bolts A and B of same material and length are subjected to identical tensile load. If the elastic strain  energy stored in bolt A is 4 times that of bolt B and the mean diameter of bolt A is 12 mm, the mean diameter of bolt B in mm is
solution: Given: [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{1}&=P_{2}=P\\ &\text{(identical tensile load on bolt A \& B )} \\ &\qquad \text{(same length)}\\ L_{1} &=L_{2}=L \\ d_{A} &=12 \mathrm{mm} \\ U_{A} &=\text { strain energy in bolt } A \\ U_{B} &=\text { Strain energy in bolt } B \\ U_{A} &=4 U_{B}(\text { Given }) \qquad \cdots(i)\\ \therefore \quad d_{B} &=? \end{aligned}[/latex] Strain energy is given by [latex] U_{A}=\frac{1}{2} P \times \delta=\frac{1}{2} \frac{P^{2} L}{A E}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Eq. (i) [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{1 P_{1}^{2} L_{1}}{2} &=4 \times \frac{1}{2} \frac{P_{2}^{2} L_{2}}{A_{2} E} \\ \frac{1}{A_{1}} &=4 \times \frac{1}{A_{2}} \\ \frac{4}{\pi(12)^{2}} &=4 \times \frac{4}{\pi\left(d_{B}\right)^{2}} \\ d_{B}^{2} &=576 \\ d_{B} &=24 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 142 A rod of length L having uniform cross-sectional area A is subjected to a tensile force P as shown in the figure below. If the Young's modulus of the material varies linearly from [latex]E_{1}[/latex]
 to [latex]E_{2}[/latex]
 along the length of the rod, the normal stress developed at the section-SS is
solution: Normal stress at any section is independent of modulus of elasticity.

question: Question 143 A solid steel cube constrained on all six face is heated so that the temperature rises uniformly by [latex]\Delta[/latex]T. If the thermal coefficient of the material is [latex]\alpha[/latex], young's modulus is E and the Poisson's ratio is [latex]v[/latex], the thermal stress developed in the cube due to heating is
solution: Let the side of cube be a Now since the cube is uniformly constrained to expand, the stress produced in all the three directions will be same [latex] \therefore [/latex] Strain in x direction [latex] \begin{aligned} &=-\alpha(\Delta T)=\frac{\sigma_{x}}{E}-\frac{v \sigma_{y}}{E}-\frac{v \sigma_{x}}{E} \\ \sigma_{x}&=\sigma_{y}=\sigma_{z}=\sigma \\ \therefore \sigma&=-\frac{\alpha(\Delta T) E}{(1-2 v)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 144 The state of stress at a point under plane stress condition is [latex]\sigma _{xx}[/latex]
 = 40MPa, [latex]\sigma _{yy}[/latex]
 = 100MPa and [latex]\tau _{xy}[/latex]
= 40MPa. The radius of the Mohr's circle representing the given state of stress in MPa is
solution: Mohr's circle [latex] R=\sqrt{(40)^{2}+(30)^{2}}=50 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 145 The homogeneous state of stress for a metal part undergoing plastic deformation is [latex]T=\begin{pmatrix} 10 & 5 & 0\\ 5 & 20 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & -10 \end{pmatrix}[/latex] Where the stress component values are in MPa. Using von Mises yield criterion, the value of estimated shear yield stress, in MPa is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \sigma_{x}=10, \sigma_{y}=20, \tau_{x y}=5, \sigma_{z}=-10 \\ \sigma_{1,2}=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ \begin{aligned} \sigma_{1}&=15+\sqrt{25+25} \\ \sigma_{1}&=22.07 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma_{2}&=7.07 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma_{3}&=\sigma_{z}=-10 \quad\left[\text { as } \tau_{x z}=\tau_{y z}=0\right] \\ \sigma_{y t}&=\text { yield stress in tension } \\ \sigma_{y s}&=\text { yield stress in shear } \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex] According to Von Mises theory [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(\sigma_{y t}\right)^{2} \geq & \frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\sigma_{2}-\sigma_{3}\right)^{2}+\left(\sigma_{3}-\sigma_{1}\right)^{2}\right] \\ \left(\sigma_{y t}\right)^{2} & \geq 772.435 \\ \sigma_{y t} & \geq 27.79 \\ \text { Now } & \sigma_{y s}=\frac{\sigma_{y t}}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \therefore \quad & \sigma_{y s}=16.046 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 146 For a long slender column of uniform cross section, the ratio of critical buckling load for the case with both ends clamped to the case with both ends hinged is
solution: Euler's buckling load, [latex] P_{e}=\frac{n \pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{L^{2}}[/latex] n=4 for both end clamped (fixed) n=1 for both end hinged [latex] \therefore [/latex] Ratio =4

question: Question 147 A cantilever beam of length L is subjected to a moment M at the free end. The moment of inertia of the beam cross section about the neutral axis is I and the young's modulus is E. the magnitude of the maximum deflection is
solution: Deflection [latex] =\frac{1}{E I}(\text { Moment of area of BMD }) [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1}{E I} \times M \times L \times \frac{L}{2}=\frac{M L^{2}}{2 E I}[/latex]

question: Question 148 A thin walled spherical shell is subjected to an internal pressure. If the radius of the shell is increased by 1% and the thickness is reduced by 1%, with the internal pressure remaining the same, the percentage change  in the circumferential (hoop) stress is
solution: Hoop stress [latex]=\frac{p d}{4 t}[/latex] p= internal pressure d= diameter of shell t= thickness of shell [latex] \begin{array}{l} \text { Now } \sigma=\frac{p d^{\prime}}{4 t^{\prime}} \\ \begin{aligned} d^{\prime}=1.01 d &\; \text { and } t^{\prime}=0.99 t \\ \therefore \quad \sigma^{\prime} &=\frac{p \times 1.01 d}{4 \times 0.99 t}=1.0202 \sigma \\ \text { \% change } &=\frac{\sigma^{\prime}-\sigma}{\sigma} \times 100 \\ &=\frac{(1.0202-1) \sigma}{\sigma} \times 100=2.02 \% \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 149 A triangular-shaped cantilever beam of uniform-thickness is shown in the figure. The Young's modulus of the material of the beam is E. A concentrated load P is applied at the free end of the beam. The maximum deflection of the beam is
solution: Using the Double-Integration method to find out the deflection, given by [latex]\begin{aligned} EI\frac{\mathrm{d}^2 y}{\mathrm{d} x^2}=-M&=-(-Px)\\ E\frac{bxt^3}{12l}\times\frac{\mathrm{d}^2 y}{\mathrm{d} x^2}&=Px\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}^2 y}{\mathrm{d} x^2}&=\frac{12Pl}{Ebt^3} \end{aligned}[/latex] On integrating, we get [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=\frac{12Plx}{Ebt^3}+C_1 \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] We know that, at  [latex]x=l;\;\;\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}=0[/latex] [latex]0=\frac{12Pl^2}{Ebt^3}+C_1[/latex] [latex]C_1=-\frac{12Pl^2}{Ebt^3}[/latex] Integrating (i), we get [latex]y=\frac{12Pl}{Ebt^3}\times\frac{x^2}{2}-\frac{12Pl^2}{Ebt^3} x+C_2[/latex] At  [latex]x=l;\;\;y=0[/latex] [latex]0=\frac{12Pl}{Ebt^3}\times\frac{l^2}{2}-\frac{12Pl^2}{Ebt^3} l+C_2[/latex] [latex]C_2=-\frac{6Pl^3}{Ebt^3}+\frac{12Pl^3}{Ebt^3}[/latex] [latex]C_2=\frac{6Pl^3}{Ebt^3}[/latex] Hence, we have [latex]y=\frac{6Plx^2}{Ebt^3}-\frac{12Pl^2x}{Ebt^3} +\frac{6Pl^3}{Ebt^3}[/latex] The maximum deflection will occur at x=0 , So [latex]y=0-0 +\frac{6Pl^3}{Ebt^3}[/latex] [latex]y=\frac{6Pl^3}{Ebt^3}[/latex]

question: Question 150 A triangular-shaped cantilever beam of uniform-thickness is shown in the figure. The Young's modulus of the material of the beam is E. A concentrated load P is applied at the free end of the beam. The area moment of inertia about the neutral axis of a cross-section at a distance x measured from the free end is
solution: Let, b = width of the base of triangle ABD = BD t = thickness of conilever beam From the similar triangle [latex]\Delta ABC[/latex]  or [latex]\Delta AFE[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{b/2}{l}&=\frac{h}{x} \\ h&=\frac{bx}{2l} \end{aligned}[/latex] For a rectangular cross section, [latex]\begin{aligned} I&=\frac{2ht^3}{12}\\&=2 \times \frac{bx}{2l} \times \frac{t^3}{12} \\ I&=\frac{bxt^3}{12l} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 151 A torque T is applied at the free end of a stepped rod of circular cross-sections as shown in the figure. The shear modulus of the material of the rod is G. The expression for d to produce an angular twist [latex]\theta[/latex]
 at the free end is
solution: By using torsion equation we have [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T}{J} &=\frac{\tau}{r}=\frac{G \theta}{L} \\ \therefore \quad \theta &=\frac{T L}{G J} \\ \therefore \quad \theta&=\frac{T\left(\frac{L}{2}\right)}{G\left(\frac{\pi}{32}\right) d^{4}}\left[\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{16}\right] \\ \theta&=\frac{T L}{G\left(\frac{\pi}{32} d^{4}\right)} \times\left(\frac{9}{16}\right) \\ \theta&=\frac{18 T L}{G \pi d^{4}} \\ \text{or}\quad d&=\left(\frac{18 T L}{\pi \theta G}\right)^{1 / 4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 152 A thin cylinder of inner radius 500mm and thickness 10mm is subjected to an internal pressure of 5MPa. The average circumferential (hoop) stress in MPa is
solution: Circumferential or hoop stress. [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{h}&=\frac{p d}{2 t}\\ \text{where }p&=5 \mathrm{MPa} \\ d &=1000 \mathrm{mm} \\ t &=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma_{H} &=\frac{5 \times 1000}{2 \times 10}=250 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 153 Match the following criteria of material failure, under biaxial stresses [latex]\sigma _{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]\sigma _{2}[/latex]
 yield stress [latex]\sigma _{y}[/latex]
 with their corresponding graphic representations :
Question 154 A column has a rectangular cross-section of 10mm x 20mm and a length of 1m. The slenderness ratio of the column is close to
solution: Assuming both ends of column to be hinged. Given: [latex] \begin{aligned} \qquad L_{\mathrm{eq}}&=1 \mathrm{m} \\ \text { Slenderness ratio }&=\frac{\mathrm{L}_{\mathrm{eq}}}{r_{\min }} \\ r_{\min }= \sqrt{\frac{I_{\min }}{A}}&=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{12} \times(10)^{3} \times 20 \times 10^{-12}} }{10 \times 20 \times 10^{-6}}\\ &=2.88 \times 10^{-3}\\ \text{Slenderness }&=\frac{1}{2.88 \times 10^{-3}}=347.22 \approx 346 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 155 A simply supported beam PQ is loaded by a moment of 1kN-m at the mid-span of the beam as shown in the figure. The reaction forces [latex]R_{P}[/latex]
 and [latex]R_{Q}[/latex]
 at supports P and Q respectively are
solution: Let us assume the direction of [latex]R_{P}[/latex] and [latex]R_{Q}[/latex] as , upward. Now, [latex] \therefore \quad R_{P}+R_{Q}=0 [/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex]Taking moment about point Q we get: [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{P} \times 1+1 &=0 \\ R_{P} &=-1 \mathrm{kN}\\ \therefore R_{Q}&=+1 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] since our assume direction of [latex]R_{p}[/latex] is wrong therefore [latex] R_{P}=1 \mathrm{kN} [/latex] which act in the down was direction and [latex] R_{Q}=1 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] acting in upward direction.

question: Question 156 A massless beam has a loading pattern as shown in the figure. The beam is of rectangular cross-section with a width of 30mm and height of 100mm. The maximum magnitude of bending stress (in MPa) is given by
solution: Maximum bending moment [latex] \begin{aligned} (\mathrm{BM})_{\max } &=1500 x-\frac{3000}{2}(x-2)^{2} \\ &=1500 \times 2.5-1500(0.5)^{2} \\ &=3375 \mathrm{Nm} \end{aligned}[/latex] Bending stress, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma &=\frac{M}{z} \\ \text { where } \quad z &=\frac{1}{6} b d^{2} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma &=\frac{6 \times 3375}{30 \times 100^{2} \times 10^{-9}} \\ &=67.5 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}=67.5 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 157 A massless beam has a loading pattern as shown in the figure. The beam is of rectangular cross-section with a width of 30mm and height of 100mm. The maximum bending moment occurs at
solution: [latex] R_{A}+R_{B}=6000 N[/latex] Taking moment about A [latex] \begin{aligned} 600 \times 3-R_{C} \times 4 &=0 \\ R_{C} &=4500 \mathrm{N}\\ R_{A}&=1500 N \end{aligned}[/latex] Taking any section x m from A [latex] \text { Shear force }=1500-3000(x-2)[/latex] and maximum bending moment occurs where shear force =0 [latex] \begin{array}{r} \Rightarrow 1500-3000(x-2)=0 \\ x=2.5 \mathrm{m} \end{array}[/latex] or 2500mm from A

question:
Question 158 The state of plane-stress at a point is given by [latex]\sigma _{x}= -200MPa, \sigma _{y}=100MPa[/latex]
and [latex]\tau _{xy}=100MPa[/latex]. The maximum shear stress in MPa is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \ln \operatorname{plane}, \tau_{\max } &=\sqrt{\left((\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y})/2\right)^{2}+ \tau_{x y}^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{150^{2}+ \times 100^{2}} \\ &=180.3 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 159 A frame of two arms of equal length L is shown in the adjacent figure. The flexural rigidity of each arm of the frame is EI. The vertical deflection at the point of application of load P is
solution: For arm AB: At ant section X-X, at a distance x frome A [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{x} &=-P x \\ U_{A B} &=\int \frac{M_{x}^{2} d x}{2 E I}=\int_{0}^{L} \frac{(-P x)^{2}}{2 E I} d x \\ U_{A B} &=\frac{P^{2}}{2 E I}\left(\frac{x^{3}}{3}\right)_{0}^{L}=\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{6 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex] For arm BC: [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{B}+R_{C} &=0 \\ M_{C} &=0 \\ R_{B} L-P L &=0 \\ R_{B} &=P \\ R_{C} &=-P \\ M_{x} &=R_{C} x=P_{x} \\ U_{B C} &=\int_{0}^{L} \frac{M_{x}^{2} d x}{2 E I}=\int_{0}^{L} \frac{P^{2} x^{2} d x}{2 E I} \\ &=\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{6 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex] Total strain energy sotred in the frame of two arm [latex] \begin{array}{l} U=U_{A B}+U_{B C} \\ U=\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{6 E I}+\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{6 E I}=\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{3 E I} \end{array}[/latex] Therefore, vertical deflection of A is [latex] \delta_{A}=\frac{\partial U}{\partial P}=\frac{\partial}{\partial P}\left[\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{3 E I}\right]=\frac{2 P L^{3}}{3 E I}[/latex]

question:
Question 160 A solid shaft of diameter, d and length L is fixed at both the ends. A torque, [latex]T_{0}[/latex]
 is applied at a distance, L/4 from the left end as shown in the figure given below The maximum shear stress in the shaft is
solution: Eq.1 [latex]\quad T_{1}+T_{2}=T_{0} [/latex] Eq.2 Angle of twist for both shafts at section X-X will be same. Therefore, [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{T_{1} L}{4 G J} &=\frac{T_{2} \times 3 L}{4 G J} \\ \text { Eq. (ii) } \quad \therefore \quad T_{1} &=3 T_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving (i) and (ii) [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{2}&=\frac{T_{0}}{4}, T_{1}=\frac{3 T_{0}}{4}\\ \text { Shear stress in } 1 &=\frac{16 T_{1}}{\pi d^{3}}=\frac{16}{\pi d^{3}} \times \frac{3 T_{0}}{4} \\ &=\frac{12 T_{0}}{\pi d^{3}} \\ \text { Shear stress in } 2 &=\frac{16 T_{2}}{\pi d^{3}}=\frac{16}{\pi d^{3}} \times \frac{T_{0}}{4}=\frac{4 T_{0}}{\pi d^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence maximum shear stress in shaft is [latex] \frac{12 T_{0}}{\pi d^{3}}[/latex]

question:
Question 161 A solid circular shaft of diameter d is subjected to a combined bending moment M and torque, T. The material property to be used for designing the shaft using the relation [latex]\frac{16}{\pi d^{3}}\sqrt{M^{2}+T^{2}}[/latex]
 is
solution: A solid circular shaft of diameter d is subjected to a combined bending moment Mand torque T. For design of shaft using the relation [latex] \frac{16}{\pi d^{3}} \sqrt{M^{2}+T^{2}} [/latex] the mechanical property torsional yield strength [latex]\left(S_{s y}\right) [/latex] is used. [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{e q} &=\sqrt{M^{2}+T^{2}} \\ \frac{\tau}{r} &=\frac{T_{e q}}{I_{P}} \\ \tau &=\frac{16}{\pi d^{3}} \sqrt{M^{2}+T^{2}} \\ &\leq \frac{S_{s y}}{N}(\text { for safe design }) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 162 If the principal stresses in a plane stress problem, are [latex]\sigma _{1}=100MPa,\; \sigma _{2}=40MPa[/latex]
 , the magnitude of the maximum shear stress (in MPa) will be
solution: In plane stress problem principal stresses, [latex] \sigma_{1}=100 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] [latex] \text{and  } \sigma_{2}=40 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] Magnitude of the maximum shear stress in plane stress case is given by [latex] \tau_{\max }=\frac{\sigma_{1}-\sigma_{2}}{2}=\frac{100-40}{2}=30 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 163 A cylindrical container of radius R = 1 m, wall thickness 1 mm is filled with water up to a depth of 2 m and suspended along its upper rim. The density of water is 1000kg/[latex]m^3[/latex] and acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/[latex]s^2[/latex]. The self-weight of the cylinder is negligible. The formula for hoop stress in a thin - walled cylinder can be used at all points along the height of the cylindrical container. If the Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio of the container material are 100GPa and 0.3, respectively, the axial strain in the cylinder wall at mid-depth is
solution: [latex]\therefore [/latex]Axial strain is given by [latex]\frac{\left(\sigma_{a}-\mu \sigma_{c}\right)}{E} [/latex] Axial strain at mid-depth [latex] =\frac{[10-(0.3 \times 10)] \times 10^{6}}{100 \times 10^{9}}=7 \times 10^{-5}[/latex]

question: Question 164 A cylindrical container of radius R = 1 m, wall thickness 1 mm is filled with water up to a depth of 2 m and suspended along its upper rim. The density of water is 1000kg/[latex]m^3[/latex] and acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/[latex]s^2[/latex]. The self-weight of the cylinder is negligible. The formula for hoop stress in a thin - walled cylinder can be used at all points along the height of the cylindrical container. The axial and circumferential stress [latex](\sigma_a ,\sigma_c )[/latex] experienced by the cylinder wall at mid-depth (1 m as shown) are
solution: Axial stress on side face will be due to force on the bottom face. Hence [latex]p_{\text {bottom }}[/latex] will be used for calculating axial stress on section X-X, [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{\text {bottom }} &=\rho g h=\rho g \times 2 \\ \sigma_{\text {axial }} &=\frac{p d}{4 t}=\frac{(\rho g h) d}{4 t}=\frac{(1000 \times 10 \times 2)(2 \times 1)}{4 \times 1 \times 10^{-3}} \\ &=10 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{Pa}=10 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Circumferential stress at section X -X will be due to pressure of fluid at section X-X Hence [latex]p=\rho g h=\rho g \times 1 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \sigma_{\text {circumferential }}=\frac{p d}{2 t}=\frac{(\rho g \times 1) \times 2 R}{2 t} \\ =\frac{1000 \times 10 \times 1 \times 2 \times 1}{2 \times 1 \times 10^{-3}}=10 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{Pa}=10 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text { (10, 10) MPa. } \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 165 A two dimensional fluid element rotates like a rigid body. At a point within the element, the
pressure is 1 unit. Radius of the Mohr's circle, characterizing the state of stress at the point, is
solution:
since the fluid element will be subjected to hydrostatic loading therefore Mohr circle will reduce into a point on [latex]\sigma\text{-axis}[/latex]. [latex]
\therefore [/latex]Radius of mohr circle =0 unit

question:
Question 166 The rod PQ of length L with flexural rigidity EI is hinged at both ends. For what minimum force F is
it expected to buckle?
solution: Let the axial comp-load acting on the rod is R [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{H} &=R \cos 45^{\circ} \\ R_{V} &=R \sin 45^{\circ} \\ \text{Hence,}\quad R &=\frac{F}{\cos 45^{\circ}}=\sqrt{2} F \end{aligned}[/latex] Condition for buckling, [latex]R>P_{\theta} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \sqrt{2} F &>\frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{L_{e}^{2}} \quad \text { where } L_{e}=\alpha L \\ F &>\frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{\sqrt{2} \alpha^{2} L^{2}}\\ \alpha &=1 \quad(\because \text{both ends hinged})\\ \text{Hence }\;F_{\min } &=\frac{\pi^{2} E I_{\min }}{\sqrt{2} L^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 167 A solid circular shaft of diameter 100 mm is subjected to an axial stress of 50 Mpa. It is further
subjected to a torque of 10 kNm. The maximum principal stress experienced on the shaft is
closest to
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{T}{I_{P}} &=\frac{\tau}{r} \\ \frac{10 \times 10^{6}}{\frac{\pi}{32}(100)^{4}} &=\frac{\tau}{\frac{100}{2}} \\ \text { or } &=50.95 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Maximum principal stress [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{\sigma}{2}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau^{2}} \\ &=\frac{50}{2}+\sqrt{\left(\frac{50}{2}\right)^{2}+(50.95)^{2}} \\ &=25+\sqrt{25^{2}+50.95^{2}}=82 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 168 For the component loaded with a force F as shown in the figure, the axial stress at the corner point
P is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{M}{I} & =\frac{\sigma}{y} \\ \frac{F(L-b) \times 12}{(2 b)^{4}} &=\frac{\sigma_{b}}{b} \\ \sigma_{b} &=\frac{3 F(L-b)}{4 b^{3}}\\ &\text{(due to bending)}\\ \text{and }\sigma_{a}&=\frac{F}{4 b^{2}}\\ &\text{(due to axial force)}\\ \therefore \text{Total axial stress}&\\ =\frac{3 F(L-b)}{4 b^{3}}+\frac{F}{4 b^{2}}&=\frac{3 F(L-b)}{4 b^{3}}+\frac{F b}{4 b^{3}} \\ =\frac{3 F L-3 F b+F b}{4 b^{3}}&=\frac{F(3 L-2 b)}{4 b^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 169 The strain energy stored in the beam with flexural rigidity EI and loaded as shown in the figure is
solution: Total strain energy stored is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} 2 \int_{0}^{L} \frac{(P x)^{2} d x}{2 E I}&+\frac{(P L)^{2} \cdot 2 L}{2 E I} \\ &=\frac{2 P^{2}}{2 E I} \int_{0}^{L} x^{2} d x+\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{E I} \\ &=\frac{P^{2}}{E I} \times \frac{L^{3}}{3}+\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{E I} \\ &=\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{3 E I}+\frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{E I}=\frac{4}{3} \frac{P^{2} L^{3}}{E I} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 170 An axial residual compressive stress due to a manufacturing process is present on the outer
surface of a rotating shaft subjected to bending. Under a given bending load. The fatigue life of the
shaft in the presence of the residual compressive stress is

options.B: Increased or decreased, depending on the external bending load

solution: The figure shown the Gerber's parabola. It is the characteristic curve of the fatigue life of the shaft in the presence of the residual compressive stress. The fatigue life of the material is effectively increased by the introduction of a compressive mean stress, whether applied or residual.

question: Question 171 A rod of Length L and diameter D is subjected to a tensile load P. Which of the following is sufficient to calculate the resulting change in diameter?

options.D: Both Young's modulus and shear modulus

solution: From the application of load P, the length of the rod increases by an amount of [latex]\Delta L[/latex] [latex]\Delta L=\frac{PL}{AE}=\frac{PL}{\frac{\pi}{4}D^2E}=\frac{4PL}{\pi D^2E}[/latex] And increase in length due to applied load P in axial or longitudinal direction, the shear modulus is comes in action. [latex]G=\frac{\text{Shearing stress}}{\text{Shearing strain}}=\frac{\tau _s}{\Delta L/L}=\frac{\tau _sL}{\Delta L}[/latex] So, for calculating the resulting change in diameter both young's modulus and  shear modulus are used.

question: Question 172 The transverse shear stress acting in a beam of rectangular cross-section, subjected to a transverse shear load, is

options.A: Variable with maximum at the bottom of the beam
options.B: Variable with maximum at the top of the beam
options.D: Variable with maximum at the neutral axis

solution: For a rectangle cross-section: [latex]\tau _v=\frac{FA\bar{Y}}{Ib}=\frac{6F}{bd^3}\left ( \frac{d^2}{4}-y^2 \right )F=\text{Transverse shear load}[/latex] Maximum values of [latex]\tau _v[/latex] occurs at the neutral axis where, [latex]y=0[/latex] [latex]\text{Maximum }\tau _v=\frac{6F}{bd^3}\times \frac{d^2}{4}=\frac{3F}{2bd}=\frac{3}{2}T_{mean}[/latex] [latex]T_{mean}=\frac{F}{bd}[/latex] So, transverse shear stress is variable with maximum on the neutral axis.

question: Question 173 A machine frame shown in the figure below is subjected to a horizontal force of 600 N parallel to z-direction. The maximum principle stress in MPa and the orientation of the corresponding principle plane in degrees are respectively
solution: The strees element Centre of Mohr circle [latex] =\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2}=33.95 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex] Radius of mohr circle [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\left[\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\ =\left[\left(\frac{0-67.9}{2}\right)^{2}+(56.6)^{2}\right]^{\frac{1}{2}}=66 \mathrm{MPa} \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Principal stress } &=66+33.95 \\ &=99.95=100 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sin 2 \theta &=\frac{56.6}{66} \\ \Rightarrow \quad 2 \theta &=59.04 \\ \therefore \quad 2 \theta_{p} &=120.95 \\ \theta_{p} &=60.47^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 174 A machine frame shown in the figure below is subjected to a horizontal force of 600 N parallel to z-direction. The normal and shear stresses in MPa at point P are respectively
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Normal stress: } \sigma&=\frac{32 M}{\pi d^{3}} \\ &=\frac{32 \times 600 \times 300}{\pi \times(30)^{3}} \\ &=67.9 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text { Shear stress: } \tau &=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}} \\ &=\frac{16 \times 600 \times 500}{\pi \times(30)^{3}} \\ &=56.6 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 175 A stepped steel shaft shown below is subjected to 10 Nm torque. If the modulus of rigidity is 80 GPa, the strain energy in the shaft in N mm is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Strain energy }=\frac{T^{2} L}{2 G J_{1}}+\frac{T^{2} L}{2 G J_{2}} \\ \qquad \frac{T^{2} I}{2 G}\left(\frac{1}{J_{1}}+\frac{1}{J_{2}}\right)=\frac{(10 \times 1000)^{2} \times 100}{2 \times 80 \times 1000}\\ \qquad\left[\left(\frac{32}{\pi \times(50)^{4}}+\frac{32}{\pi \times(25)^{4}}\right)\right] \\ =\frac{10^{8} \times 100 \times 32}{2 \pi \times 80 \times 1000}\left[\frac{1}{(50)^{4}}+\frac{1}{(25)^{4}}\right]=1.73 \mathrm{N}-\mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 176 A 200 x 100 x 50 mm steel block is subjected to a hydrostatic pressure of 15 MPa. The Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio of the material are 200 GPa and 0.3 respectively. The change in the volume of the block in [latex]mm^{3}[/latex]
 is
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} V &=a \times b \times c \\ &=200 \times 100 \times 50 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ &=10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{3} \\ E &=200 \mathrm{GPa} \\ \mu &=0.3 \\ \frac{d V}{V} &=\frac{3 \sigma}{E}\{1-2 \mu\} \\ d V &=\frac{3 \sigma}{E}\{1-2 \mu\} \times V \\ =& \frac{3 \times 15}{200 \times 10^{3}} \times\left\{1-(2 \times 0.3\} \times 10^{6}\right.\\ &=90 \mathrm{mm}^{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 177 A uniformly loaded propped cantilever beam and its free body diagram are shown below. The reactions are
solution: The given propped cantilever beam can be assumed to be consisting of two type of loads. First part is simple cantilever with UDL and the second part is cantilever beam with point load of [latex] R_{2} [/latex] at end. Balancing the forces we get [latex] R_{1}+R_{2}=q L \qquad \cdots(i)[/latex] Balancing the deflection at end point as net deflection at the end is zero. Deflection at B due to the UDL alone, [latex] \delta_{B}=\frac{q L^{4}}{8 E I}[/latex] Deflection at B due to [latex]R_{2}[/latex] alone, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{B}^{\prime}&=\frac{R_{2} L^{3}}{3 E I}\\ \therefore \quad \delta_{B} &=\delta_{B}^{\prime} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{q L^{4}}{8 E I} &=\frac{R_{2} L^{3}}{3 E I} \Rightarrow R_{2}=\frac{3 q L}{8} \\ \text { From (i), } \quad R_{1} &=q L-R_{2} \\ &=q L-\frac{3 q L}{8}=\frac{5 q L}{8}\\ \text{Moment: }\quad M&=R_{2} L-q L \times \frac{L}{2}\\ &=\frac{3 q L^{2}}{8}-\frac{q L^{2}}{2}=-\frac{q L^{2}}{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 178 A steel rod of length L and diameter D, fixed at both ends, is uniformly heated to a temperature rise of [latex]\Delta T[/latex]. The Young's modulus is E and the co efficient of linear expansion is  [latex]\alpha[/latex]. The thermal stress in the rod is
solution: Thermal strain, [latex] \begin{aligned} \varepsilon_{t} &=\frac{\text { Change in length prevented }}{\text { original length }}\\ &=\frac{L \alpha \Delta T}{L} \\ &=\alpha \Delta T\end{aligned}[/latex] Thermal stress, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{t} &=\varepsilon_{t} \times E \\ &=\alpha \Delta T E \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 179 In a simply - supported beam loaded as shown below, the maximum bending moment in Nm is
solution: Resultant beam diagram [latex]R_{A}+R_{B}=100 \quad \cdots(1)[/latex] Taking moment about A [latex] -100 \times 0.5-10+R_{B} \times 1=0[/latex] [latex] \therefore R_{B}=60 N[/latex] [latex] \text{and }\quad R_{A}=40 N[/latex] Bending moment diagram Maximum bending movement [latex] =40\times0.5+1.=30\text{Nm}[/latex]

question: Question 180 A simply supported beam of span length 6 m and 75 mm diameter carries a uniformly distributed load of 1.5 kN/m. What is the maximum value of bending stress?
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{M}{I} &=\frac{\sigma_{b}}{y} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma_{b} &=\frac{6.75 \times 10^{6} \times 64}{\pi \times(75)^{4}} \times \frac{75}{2} \\ &=162.97 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 181 A simply supported beam of span length 6 m and 75 mm diameter carries a uniformly distributed load of 1.5 kN/m. What is the maximum value of bending moment?
solution: F.B.D [latex] R_{A}+R_{B}=9 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Taking moment about B , we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore R_{A} \times 6&=1.5 \times 6 \times 3\\ A_{A} &=R_{B}=4.5 \mathrm{KN} \\ M_{\max } &=4.5 \times-1.5 \frac{x^{2}}{2}[at \;\mathrm{x}=3 \mathrm{m}] \\ &=6.75 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 182 A bar having a cross-sectional area of 700 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex]
 is subjected to axial loads at the positions indicated. The value of stress in the segment QR is:
solution: At face Q 35 kN force is acting towards right hence ([latex]x\gt y[/latex]) [latex] \therefore x-y=35 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] At face R 49kN force is acting towards right hence ([latex]y\gt z[/latex]) [latex] x=63 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] [on compairing P face of bar and P face of 1 [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{If}\quad x &=63 \mathrm{kN} \\ x-y &=35 \mathrm{kN} \\ y &=28 \mathrm{kN}\\ \text { If } y&=28 \mathrm{kN} \\ y-z &=49 \mathrm{kN} \\ z &=-21 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] \sigma_{QR}=\frac{28 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{N}}{700 \mathrm{mm}^{2}}=40 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question: Question 183 A steel bar of 40 mmx40 mm square cross-section is subjected to an axial compressive load of 200 kN. If the length of the bar is 2m and E = 200 GPa, the elongation of the bar will be:
solution: We know that [latex] =\frac{P L}{A E}=\frac{200 \times 10^{3} \times 2 \times 10^{3}}{40 \times 40 \times 200 \times 10^{3}}=1.25 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question: Question 184 According to Von-Mises' distortion energy theory, the distortion energy under three dimensional stress state is repreented by
solution: According to "VON MISES - HENKY THEORY", the elastic failure of a material occurs when the distortion energy of the material reaches the distortion energy at the elastic limit in simple tension. Shear strain energy due to the principle stresses [latex]\sigma _1,\sigma _2 \text{ and }\sigma _3[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta E&=\frac{1+v}{6E}\left [ (\sigma _1 -\sigma _2)^2 +(\sigma _2 -\sigma _3)^2 + (\sigma _3 -\sigma _1)^2\right ] \\ &=\frac{1+v}{6E}\left [ 2(\sigma _1^2 + \sigma _2 ^2 + \sigma _3^2) - 2 (\sigma _1 \sigma _2 + \sigma _2\sigma _3 +\sigma _3\sigma _1)\right ] \\ &= \frac{1+v}{3E}\left [ \sigma _1^2 + \sigma _2 ^2 + \sigma _3^2 - (\sigma _1 \sigma _2 + \sigma _2\sigma _3 +\sigma _3\sigma _1)\right ] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 185 A pin-ended column of length L, modulus of elasticity E and second moment of the cross-sectional area I is loaded centrically by a compressive load P. the critical buckling load [latex](P_{cr})[/latex]
 is given by
solution: [latex]P_{E}=\frac{n \pi^{2} E I}{L^{2}}[/latex] For pin-ended column n=1 Here n= End fixity coefficient E = Modulus of elasticity I = Second moment of area L = Actual length of column

question: Question 186 For a circular shaft of diameter d subjected to torque T, the maximum value of the shear stress is:
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{T}{J} &=\frac{\tau}{d / 2} \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \frac{T}{\frac{\pi}{32} d^{4}} &=\frac{\tau}{d / 2} \\ \therefore \qquad & \tau=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 187 The Mohr's circle of plane stress for a point in a body is shown. The design is to be done on the basis of the maximum shear stress theory for yielding. Then, yielding will just begin if the designer chooses a ductile material whose yield strength is
solution: As per maximum shear stress theory, [latex] \left(\tau_{\max }\right)_{\text {absolute }} \leq\left(\frac{S_{y t}}{2}\right)_{\pi}[/latex] and when [latex]\sigma_{1}[/latex] and [latex]\sigma_{2}[/latex] are like in nature [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{1} & \leq S_{y t} \\ S_{y t} &=100 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 188 A cantilever beam has the square cross section of 10 mmx 10 mm. It carries a transverse load of 10 N. considering only the bottom fibres of the beam, the correct representation of the longitudinal variation of the bending stress is
solution: The bending moment varies from zero to 10Nm along the length of the beam from the centre of the beam. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \sigma &=\frac{M}{I} \times y_{\max } \\ &=\frac{10 \times 10^{3}}{10^{4} / 12} \times \frac{10}{2}=60 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 189 A cantilever beam carries the anti-symmetric load shown, where [latex]w_0[/latex] is the peak intensity of the distributed load. Qualitatively, the correct bending moment diagram for this beam is
solution: We know that, for a uniformly varying load bending moment will be cubic in nature. We see that there is no shear force at B, so the slope of BMD at right of B must be zero and similarly on left end A there is no shear force, so slope of BMD also zero. Now due to triangular shape of load intensity, when we move from right to left, the rate of increase of shear force decreases and maximum at the middle & therefore it reduces.

question: Question 190 A beam is made up of two identical bars AB and BC, by hinging them together at B. The end A is built-in (cantilevered) and the end C is simply supported. With the load P acting as shown, the bending moment at A is
solution: Free body diagram [latex] \because \quad R_{A}+R_{C}=P[/latex] At B these is an Internal hinge [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \qquad M_{B}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad R_{C} \times L-P \times \frac{L}{2}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad R_{C}&=\frac{P}{2}\\ \therefore \quad R_{A}&=\frac{P}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] take moment about point A [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow R_{C} \times 2 L-P \times \frac{3 L}{2}+M_{A}&=0 \\ P L-\frac{3 P L}{2}+M_{A}&=0\\ \text{or }\quad M_{A}&=\frac{P L}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 191 The two shafts AB and BC, of equal length and diameters d and 2d, are made of the same material. They are joined at B through a shaft coupling, while the ends A and C are built-in (cantilevered). A twisting moment T is applied to the coupling. If [latex]T_{A}[/latex]
 and [latex]T_{C}[/latex]
 represent the twisting moments at the ends A and C, respectively, then
solution: Angular deflection in both shatts are same [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \theta_{A B} &=\theta_{B C} \\ \frac{T_{A} \times L}{G \times \frac{\pi}{32} \times d^{4}} &=\frac{T_{C} \times L}{G \times \frac{\pi}{32} \times(2 d)^{4}} \\ T_{A} &=\frac{T_{C}}{16}\\ \therefore \quad T_{C}&=16 T_{A} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 192 Two identical cantilever beams are supported as shown, with their free ends in contact through a rigid roller. After the load P is applied, the free ends will have

options.A: equal deflections but not equal slopes
options.B: equal slopes but not equal deflections
options.C: equal slopes as well as equal deflections
options.D: neither equal slopes nor equal deflections

solution: From the figure, we can say that load P applies a force on upper cantilever and the reaction force also applied on upper cantilever by the rigid roller. Due to this, deflections are occur in both the cantilever, which are equal in amount. But because of different forces applied by the P and rigid roller, the slopes are unequal.

question:
Question 193 A uniform, slender cylindrical rod is made of a homogeneous and isotropic material. The rod rests on a frictionless surface. The rod is heated uniformly. If the radial and longitudinal thermal stresses are represented by [latex]\sigma _{r}[/latex]
 and [latex]\sigma _{z}[/latex], respectively, then
solution: If a body is allowed to expand or contract freely with rise or fall in temperature then no stress are induced in body. i.e. [latex] \sigma_{r}=0 \text { and } \sigma_{z}=0[/latex]

question: Question 194 A steel beam of breadth 120 mm and height 750 mm is loaded as shown in the figure. Assume [latex]E_{steel}=200GPa[/latex] The value of maximum deflection of the beam is
solution: Moment of inertia, [latex] I=\frac{b h^{3}}{12}=\frac{120 \times(750)^{3}}{12}=42.1875 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{mm}^{4}[/latex] Maximum deflection in the beam is given by [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta &=\frac{5}{384} \frac{w L^{4}}{E I} \\ &=\frac{5}{384} \times \frac{120 \times 10^{3}}{10^{3}} \times \frac{\left(15 \times 10^{3}\right)^{4}}{200 \times 10^{3} \times 42.1875 \times 10^{8}} \\ &=93.75 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 195 A steel beam of breadth 120 mm and height 750 mm is loaded as shown in the figure. Assume [latex]E_{steel}=200GPa[/latex] The beam is subjected to a maximum bending moment of
solution: Maximum bending moment occurs at the centre [latex] =\frac{w L^{2}}{8}=\frac{120 \times(15)^{2}}{8}=3375 \mathrm{kNm}[/latex]

question: Question 196 A solid circular shaft of 60 mm diameter transmits a torque of 1600 N.m. The value of maximum shear stress develop is
solution: [latex]\tau_{\max }=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}}=\frac{16 \times 1600 \times 10^{3}}{\pi \times(60)^{3}}=37.72 \mathrm{MPa}[/latex]

question:
Question 197 The figure below shows a steel rod of [latex]25 mm^{2}[/latex]
 cross sectional area. It is loaded at four points, K, L, M and N. Assume [latex]E_{steel}=200 GPa[/latex]. The total change in length of the rod due to loading is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given: } & & \text { Area } &=25 \mathrm{mm}^{2} \\ & & E_{\text {steel }} &=200 \mathrm{GPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] At face [latex] L 250 \mathrm{N} [/latex] axial load is acting towards right hence ([latex]x \gt y[/latex]) [latex] \therefore x-y=250 N[/latex] At face [latex] M 200 \mathrm{N} [/latex] axial load is acting towards left hence ([latex]z \gt y[/latex]) [latex] \therefore z-y=200 N[/latex] x=100N [on compairing load on K face of steel rod and K face of I] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { If } \quad & x=100 \mathrm{N} \\ \text { and } \quad x-y &=250 \\ y &=-150 \mathrm{N}\\ \text{If }\quad y&=-150 \mathrm{N}\\ \text { and } \quad z-y &=200 \\ z &=50 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta l_{\mathrm{total}} &=\Delta l_{\mathrm{I}}+\Delta l_{\mathrm{II}}+\Delta l_{\mathrm{II}} \\ \Delta l_{\mathrm{I}} &=\frac{x L}{A E}=\frac{+100 \times 500}{25 \times\left\{200 \times 10^{3}\right\}}=0.01 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Delta l_{\mathrm{Il}}=\frac{y L}{A E}=\frac{-150 \times[1700-\{500+400]]}{25 \times\left\{200 \times 10^{3}\right\}}[/latex] [latex]\Delta l_{\mathrm{III}}=\frac{z L}{A E}=\frac{50 \times 400}{25 \times\left\{200 \times 10^{3}\right\}}=4 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{mm}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Delta l_{\mathrm{Total}} &=\Delta l_{1}+\Delta l_{2}+\Delta l_{3} \\ &=0.01-0.024+4 \times 10^{-3} \\ &=-0.01 \mathrm{mm}=0.01 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}\\ &=-1 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{m} \\ &= \frac{-1 \times 10^{-5} \times 10}{10} \mathrm{m}\\& =-10 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{m}=-10\mathrm{\mu m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 198 A torque of 10 Nm is transmitted through a stepped shaft as shown in figure. The torsional stiffnesses of individual sections of lengths MN, NO and OP are 20 Nm/rad, 30 Nm/rad and 60 Nm/rad respectively. The angular deflection between the ends M and P of the shaft is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta_{M N}&=\frac{10}{20}=\frac{10}{20} \text { radian } \\ \theta_{N O}&=\frac{10}{30}=\frac{10}{30} \text { radian } \\ \theta_{O P}&=\frac{10}{60}= \frac{10}{60} \text { radian } \end{aligned}[/latex] The parts MN, NO and OP are connected in series. [latex] \theta_{M P}=\theta_{M N}+\theta_{N O}+\theta_{O P}=1 \text { radian }[/latex]

question: Question 199 The figure shows the state of stress at a certain point in a stressed body. The magnitudes of normal stresses in the x and y direction are 100 MPa and 20 MPA respectively. The radius of Mohr's stress circle representing this state of stress is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Radius } &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}} \\ \text{Given,} \quad \sigma_{x} &=100 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma_{y}&=-20 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \tau_{x y} &=0 \\ \therefore \text { Radius } &=\sqrt{\left(\frac{100+20}{2}\right)^{2}+0} \\ &=60 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 200 In terms of Poission's ratio (v) the ratio of Young's Modulus (E) to Shear Modulus (G) of elastic materials is
solution: We know that [latex] \begin{aligned} E &=2 G(1+v) \\ \text{or}\quad \frac{E}{G} &=2(1+v) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 201 The state of stress at a point "P" in a two dimensional loading is such that the Mohr's circle is a point located at 175 MPa on the positive normal stress axis. Determine the directions of maximum and minimum principal stresses at the point "P" from the Mohr's circle
solution: Mohr's circle is a point, hence maximum and minimum stress at point  P is same in all directions.

question: Question 202 The state of stress at a point "P" in a two dimensional loading is such that the Mohr's circle is a point located at 175 MPa on the positive normal stress axis. Determine the maximum and minimum principal stresses respectively from the Mohr's circle
solution: Mohr's circle is a point [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { i.e., } \quad& \sigma_{1} &=\sigma_{2}=175 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \text { and } \quad& \tau_{\max } &=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 203 A shaft subjected to torsion experiences a pure shear stress [latex]\tau[/latex]
 on the surface. The maximum principal stress on the surface which is at [latex]45^{\circ}[/latex]
 to the axis will have a value
solution: [latex]\sigma_{1 / 2}=\frac{\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}}{2} \pm \sqrt{\left(\frac{\sigma_{x}-\sigma_{y}}{2}\right)^{2}+\tau_{x y}^{2}}[/latex] For pure shear, [latex] \begin{array}{l} \sigma_{x} \text { and } \sigma_{y}=0 \text { and } \tau_{x y}=\tau \\ \Rightarrow \sigma_{1 / 2}=0 \pm \sqrt{\tau^{2}}=\pm \tau \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] Maximum principal stress [latex]=\tau [/latex] It can be written as [latex]2 \tau \sin 45^{\circ} \cos 45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] =2 \times \tau \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\tau[/latex]

question: Question 204 A simply supported laterally loaded beam was found to deflect more than a specified value. Which of the following measures will reduce the deflection?

options.A: Increase the area moment of inertia
options.B: Increase the span of the beam
options.C: Select a different material having lesser modulus of elasticity
options.D: Magnitude of the load to be increased

solution: From differential equation of elastic curve [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} &=\frac{M}{E I} \\ \therefore \quad y &=\frac{1}{E I} \iint M d x+C_{1} x+C_{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] As area moment (I) increases, the deflection (y) will reduce.

question: Question 205 Maximum shear stress developed on the surface of a solid circular shaft under pure torsion is 240 MPa. If the shaft diameter is doubled then the maximum shear stress developed corresponding to the same torque will be
solution: [latex]\tau_{\max }=\frac{16 T}{\pi d^{3}}=240[/latex] When shaft diameter is doubled then [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau_{\max }^{\prime} &=\frac{16 \mathrm{T}}{\pi(2 \mathrm{d})^{3}}=\frac{16 \mathrm{T}}{8 \pi \mathrm{d}^{3}} \\ &=\frac{\tau_{\max }}{8}=\frac{240}{8} \\ \tau_{\max }^{\prime} &=30 \mathrm{MPa} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 206 Two beams, one having square cross section and another circular cross-section, are subjected to the same amount of bending moment. If the cross sectional area as well as the material of both the beams are the same then

options.A: maximum bending stress developed in both the beams is the same
options.B: the circular beam experiences more bending stress than the square one
options.C: the square beam experiences more bending stress than the circular one
options.D: as the material is same both the beams will experience same deformation

solution: Let, d= diameter of circular cross-section a= side of square cross-section since cross-sectional area of square and circular cross-section are equal [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}=a^{2}\quad \cdots(i)[/latex] For circular cross-section, [latex] \sigma_{c}=\frac{M y}{I}=\frac{M \cdot \frac{d}{2}}{\frac{\pi d^{4}}{64}}=\frac{32 M}{\pi d^{3}}[/latex] Square cross-section, [latex] \begin{aligned} \sigma_{s} &=\frac{M \cdot y}{I} \\ &=\frac{M \frac{a}{2}}{\frac{a^{4}}{12}}=\frac{6 M}{a^{3}} \\ \text{Now}\quad \frac{\sigma_{c}}{\sigma_{s}} &=\frac{\frac{32 M}{\pi d^{3}}}{\frac{6 M}{a^{3}}}=\frac{32 a^{3}}{6 \pi d^{3}}\\ &=\frac{32}{6 \pi}\left(\frac{a}{d}\right)^{2}\left(\frac{a}{d}\right) \\ &=\frac{32}{6 \pi} \times\left(\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \times\left(\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{4}}\right) \\ &=\frac{32}{24} \sqrt{\frac{\pi}{4}}=\frac{32 \sqrt{\pi}}{48}>1 \\ \sigma_{c}&> \sigma_{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 207 Two identical circular rods of same diameter and same length are subjected to same magnitude of axial tensile force. One of the rods is made out of mild steel having the modulus of elasticity of 206 GPa. The other rod is made out of cast iron having the modulus of elasticity of 100 GPa. Assume both the materials to be homogeneous and isotropic and the axial force causes the same amount of uniform stress in both the roads. The stresses developed are within the proportional limit of the respective materials. Which of the following observation is correct?

options.A: Both rods elongate by the same amount
options.B: Mild steel rod elongates more than the cast iron rod
options.C: Cast iron rod elongates more than the mild steel rod
options.D: As the stresses are equal strains are also equal in both the rods

solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\quad E_{S}&=206 \mathrm{GPa} \\ \text{and}\quad E_{I}&=100 \mathrm{GPa} \end{aligned}[/latex] Elongation in mild steel, [latex] \Delta L_{s}=\frac{P L}{A E_{s}} \qquad\cdots(i)[/latex] Elongation in cast Iron, [latex] \Delta L_{1}=\frac{P L}{A E_{I}} \qquad\cdots(ii)[/latex] Dividing Eq. (ii) by Eq. (i), we get [latex] \frac{\Delta L_{s}}{\Delta L_{l}}=\frac{E_{I}}{E_{S}}[/latex] since diameter and length of both shafts are equal [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{\Delta L_{S}}{\Delta L_{I}}=\frac{100}{206} \lt 1[/latex]

question:
Question 208 A concentrated load of P acts on a simply supported beam of span L at a distance [latex]\frac{L}{3}[/latex]
 form the left support. The bending moment at the point of application of the load is given by
solution: Taking moment about A, we have [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{B} \times L &=P \times \frac{L}{3} \\ \therefore \quad R_{B} &=\frac{P}{3}\\ \text{and }\quad R_{A}=P-R_{B}&=P-\frac{P}{3}\\ R_{A}&=\frac{2 P}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Bending moment at the point of application of load, [latex] M=\frac{2 P}{3} \times \frac{L}{3}=\frac{2 P L}{9}[/latex]

question: Question 209 The second moment of a circular area about the diameter is given by (D is the diameter).
solution: Polar moment of inertia perpendicular to the plane of paper [latex] I_{p}=\frac{\pi D^{4}}{32}[/latex] By 'Perpendicular Axis" theorem [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{x x}+I_{y y} &=I_{p} \quad\left[\because I_{x x}=I_{y y}\right] \\ 2 I_{x x} &=\frac{\pi D^{4}}{32} \\ \therefore \quad I_{x x} &=I_{y y}=\frac{\pi D^{4}}{64} \end{aligned}[/latex]
